Title: Rajinikanth’s spiritual politics will not eat into our vote base: BJP
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Hariharan Raja Sharma

Title: Hyderabad: Robbers steal Rs 70,000 cash from businessman
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Robbers snatched away the cash bag of a businessman at Satosh Nagar on Sunday night after sprinkling chilli powder in his eyes.

According to Santosh Nagar inspector A Bhojya, the victim, Adil, of Malakpet was collecting cash from various chicken shops in the city on Sunday night when the incident happened.

When he was going to Baba Nagar, two offenders sprinkled chilli powder in his eyes near Rakshapuram and snatched away the hand bag containing Rs 70,000, the inspector said.

Title: University of Mysore hostels under lens after allegations of outsiders staying there
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

MYSURU: After some students and research scholars were booked for sedition along with alumni of University of Mysore , varsity authorities have decided to throw out illegal occupants from its hostels.

Hundreds of students stay in PG blocks on campus and though they’re single occupancy rooms, more than two or three people stay in most rooms, claims syndicate member EC Ningaraja Gowda.

He added that since there’s no strict vigil on hostels, outsiders take advantage of the situation and stay there. “I have information that some rooms are being rented out and alumni are allowed to stay there. This is not good for an institution like University of Mysore that has a long cherished history,” he said.

The recent incident wherein varsity alumni, research scholars and students were named in a sedition case has badly dented its image, he said.

The syndicate has resolved to hold dean and hostel wardens responsible for any misuse of varsity property, especially hostels, hereafter and have suggested a round-the-clock vigil, he added.

There are three PG blocks each for men and women on the varsity campus.

A reality check by TOI revealed that since there’s no restrictions on entry, anyone can enter hostel blocks and stay inside in rooms. In women’s block, there is round-the-clock vigil. An employee said there are three blocks for girl students and entry is restricted. Every block is manned by a security guard. “Since the guard has gone for lunch, I’ve been at the gate. We know our inmates and don’t allow outsider inside,” she said.

R Shivappa, registrar, said a committee including syndicate members has been appointed to check the hostels. “Once the committee submits its report, we’ll take legal action as per university and hostel rules if there are any illegal occupants,” he said.

He added that there are allegations about hostel management. “Let the committee give its report and based on it, we’ll proceed,” he said. According to him, there are 18 hostels, including working women’s hostel, in Mysuru, Mandya, Hassan and Chamarajanagara, with 4,100 residents.

Title: Ooty municipality asks encroachers to vacate pavements, water bodies
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

UDHAGAMANDALAM: The Ooty municipality has warned encroachers who have occupied water bodies , pavements and road to vacate encroachments themselves or face action.

Municipal commissioner Saraswathi said petty shops like mobile repair shops and milk parlours have been mushrooming on pavements, roads and water bodies. “So we published a notice in vernacular dailies asking the encroachers to vacate the spots. Otherwise, the municipality will evict them soon,” the commissioner said. Most of the shops put their products, display boards and other items on the encroached spots, she said

Etienne’s Road, Commercial Road, Garden Road, Lake Road, Hospital Road and Walsham Road are key roads encroached in Ooty town. “We have started an exercise to identify the encroachments and serve notices to encroachers,” Saraswathi said.

An activist, on a condition of anonymity, said shop keepers were using the pavements to keep their merchandise and other materials for display. “Pedestrians and motorists are put into hardship because of this,” the activist said.

Title: Mysuru: Pourakarmikas seek citizens’ vote for Swachh Survekshan feedback
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

Title: Sons of Telugu soil elated and humbled by Padma Shri honour
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Real achievement will be when people adopt organic farming techniques

Preeti Biswas

Secunderabad: My real achievement would be when people start using my organic farming techniques at large and adopt healthy eating as a way of life, said Chintala Venkat Reddy, who was conferred with Padma Shri on January 25.

He was one among three people from Telangana to have received the prestigious award. Born in Alwal, Hyderabad in an agriculture family, he always had keen interest in agriculture. His invention that improves soil fertility also attracted the Presidents of the United States of America, Bill Clinton in 2001 and George W Bush in 2006 during their visit to Hyderabad.

“I don’t use any fertilizer, insecticides or fungicides for agriculture. Every soil has natural nutrients that can be utilised for farming. My mantra is to rejuvenate top layer of soil to reduce depletion of nutrients,” said Reddy.

For Reddy, Padma Shri is only a recognition that will help him spread the word about the novel techniques that he has developed in agriculture. Although his techniques have received patents from many countries in Europe, South Africa, Australia to name a few, he wants them to be widely and freely used by growers and cultivators.

“There is very little research into organic farming or agriculture field. Even if there are any, they fail to reach the masses. Purpose of developing new techniques is not to secure patents but to spread them widely,” said Reddy.

Now an expert into grape farming, he replicated the soil fertility technology in rice, wheat and black grapes which lead to high yields and high nutritive value. He was awarded with Uttam Rythu Puraskar award by former chief minister of Andhra Pradesh YS Rajashekar Reddy in January, 2006 and a national award at India-Agri Award in New Delhi in February 2012.

—

It’s the biggest recognition for me, says puppeteer Chalapathi Rao

Sandeep Raghavan

Tirupati: Puppeteer Dalavai Chalapathi Rao is mighty elated after being selected for the Padma Shri. “This is the biggest recognition I could ever get for dedicating my life for keeping alive the folk art form, which is fading away in the modern age,” Chalapathi Rao told TOI as he received neighbours and friends congratulating him.

Born in 1936 at the sleepy village of Nimmalakunta near Dharmavaram in Anantapur district, Chalapathi Rao was attracted to puppet shows quite early. He learnt the art from his father Khade Rao at an early age of 13.

And for the next five decades, Chalapathi Rao along with his group of eight artistes gave several puppet shows, mostly revolving around mythological themes. Some of his most popular performances are from the Ramayana and the Mahabharata.

Chalapathi Rao and his troupe also rendered performances in the USA, Germany and France more than 65 times. As years passed by, Chalapathi Rao turned a teacher and inspiration for the youngsters at his village who took up puppet shows as their source of livelihood.

Of late, Chalapathi Rao along with his family members began training craftsman in making leather paintings, lamp shades, room partitions etc, as the art form began slowly fading away.

Chalapathi Rao, 84, said this is the biggest prize of his life. ‘‘I won a national award in 1988 and several other awards later. But nothing can be compared to being conferred a Padma Shri”, he said.

Celebrations erupted all around at Dharmavaram and Nimmalakunta where people queued up to congratulate Chalapathi Rao.

------

Five-decade passion for acting, Gopala Rao finally gets Padma Shri

J Umamaheswara Rao

Visakhapatnam: After five decades on stage and more than 5,600 theatre appearances, Yadla Gopala Rao, who became a household name for his acting prowess in Srikakulam district, has finally been recognised for his yeoman services to Telugu theatre when the Union government announced Padma Shri to him on Saturday.

Starting his theatre career as an adolescent, he had donned many a role in both mythological and social dramas. But Rao found his forte in enacting the roles of mythological heroes such as Lord Krishna, Lord Rama and Sage Narada.

His ‘Nakshatraka’ role in ‘Satya Harishchandra’ play stands out among all others.

Gopala Rao has been a recipient of several state and regional awards and is extremely popular on YouTube through his acting videos. Known for his skills in classical poem recital, he even donned the role of a movie producer when he made a movie of the lyrical play, “Satya Harishchandra,” in its original form. The movie, released in 2013, received much critical acclaim.

Speaking to ToI, the 70-year-old noted theatre personality said that he is happy to get the award at a time when the mythological plays have been witnessing a declining interest among the public.

“I derived true pleasure in stage plays for the last five decades and contributed my bit to the arts. My efforts and contributions to the theatre have finally paid off through the award,” said Rao.

Rao was born in Mandarada village in Santakaviti Mandal in 1950 and completed his PUC (pre-university course) in the Government College, Srikakulam in 1964. He made his stage debut as early as in 1964 when he was 14 in a social drama named ‘Desam Kosam’ (for the country). He earned a huge fan base not only in Andhra Pradesh, but also in Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Odisha, etc. through his theatre performances.

All that I know, I learnt from my mother

Karimnagar: Litterateur and Sanskrit scholar Vijayasarathi Sribhashyam described the Padma Shri award as rare recognition for Sanskrit literature and language.

“My mother Gopamamba is my mentor and teacher. All that I know about Sanskrit, I learnt from her,” Vijayasarathi said. Vijayasarathi’s wife Hemalatha and son Varaprasad are elated over the recognition.

Vijayasarthi who was born in Chegurthi village in Karimnagar had his primary education in Urdu medium. His interest in Sanksrit propelled him to learn the language and Vijayasarathi took to composing Sanskrit poetry at the age of eight. He went on to author over a 100 books. He pioneered the use of several new genres and modes of expression in Sanskrit. He introduced ‘seesam’, a telugu indigenous poetic form, and was also the first one to introduce epistolary form in Sanskrit literature. His work Mandakini shot him to fame and won him laurels in India and abroad. Vijayasarath also has the distinction of using the maximum number of ‘dhatus’ in his poems.

In the year 2017, chief minister K Chandrashekhar Rao had honored him with the Sanskrit Scholar award on the eve of Independence Day at Golconda fort, the family recalls with pride. Several literary scholars and fans of Vijayasarathis work expresses joy over the award being presented to the scholar.

Title: Salem: Man stopped from setting himself on fire
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

COIMBATORE: A 35-year-old man was prevented from immolating himself inside the Salem district court campus at Asthampatti during the Republic Day celebrations on Sunday.

Police said Venkatachalam, a loadman from Kozhinjipatti near Salem, poured petrol and attempted to set fire to himself. A judge and a few other police personnel noticed it and prevented him from taking the extreme step.

Venkatachalam was later handed over to the Asthampatti police. During the preliminary inquiry, Venkatachalam said he was in a relationship with a widow and he was depressed after she refused to marry him. Further investigation is on.

Title: Numismatic society advises TTD to preserve antique coins
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

The TTD may be selling demonetised and out of circulation coins to Steel Authority of India Limited based on their intrinsic value, while the numismatic value of these coins is several dozen times higher. Some of the coins are rare and command a price of thousands of rupees in the world numismatic market.

Coin experts suggest that the TTD segregate the coins based on their antique or numismatic value and dispose of the others. TTD, which is a quasi-government body, cannot sell demonetised and out of circulation coins at a price higher than their face value, though the coins command a higher price in the numismatic market.

A group of numismatists from the South Indian Numismatic Society led by its vice-president D Raja Reddy were engaged by the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams to advice it on sorting out the coins. The group spent nearly six months at TTD treasury and Parakamani wing at Tirupati. What had astonished the group was the hundi at Tirumala was receiving gold coins minted as early as 1st century CE even in the 21st century.

The group had advised the temple administration to preserve coins minted before 1947 as they carry historical significance while other voluminous coins minted after 1950s could be disposed of as per government procedures.

Books written by Raja Reddy and Narasimha Murthy titled ‘‘Gold coins in the Srivari Hundi of Lord Venkateswara” and ‘‘Silver, copper and other metal coins in the Srivari Hundi of Lord Venkateswara” were published by the TTD in 2012, copies of which were presented to Prime Minister of India Narendra Modi during his pilgrimage to the Tirumala temple in June, 2019.

These books brought out by the TTD have a detailed historical and numismatic information on 1,213 gold coins and 1,382 coins made of silver, copper and other metals, with some even dating back to the Roman period.

Raja Reddy said the temple administration was already sitting on a coins pile up of over 20 tonnes of demonetised coins around 2012. ‘‘We asked TTD to preserve coins before Indian independence and to dispose of coins minted after 1947 following due governmental procedures” , he added.

Raja Reddy pointed out that a number of coin collectors and traders were selling these demonetized coins online and offline at exorbitant prices.

‘’Some traders are selling 25 paise Indian coins anywhere between Rs 5,000 and Rs 25,000 per piece in the open market and online. But TTD being a quasi government institute cannot adopt similar means to dispose of the demonetized coins. TTD is trying to dispose of its demonetised coins through SAIL by following the guidelines laid down by the Reserve Bank of India and the security printing and minting corporation of India limited (SPMCIL) is the right way of disposal of the out of circulation coins’‘, said Raja Reddy.

Title: Tahsildar leads the Republic Day celebrations in Hubballi
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

HUBBALI: The 71st Republic Day was celebrated here on Sunday with tahsildar Shashidhar Madyal unfurling the tricolour at the Republic Day function organised by taluk administration.

In his address, Madyal said the government has taken the effort to reach out to people in need after floods ravaged the city and surrounding areas. “ Compensation to the tune of Rs 27.4 crore was given to people to restore their life back to normalcy,” he added.

He also called on citizens to keep the city clean. “All should participate in Swachh Bharat Sarvekshan by downloading the application. Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation will address the issues of people within 48 hours of registration of complaint.

After the flag hoisting, Madyal received guard of honour from the parade of police, home guards, students and NCC cadets.

MLCs Basavaraj Horatti, Srinivas Mane and Pradeep Shettar attended the function along with freedom fighter K G Kulkarni, Srinivas Tembe, Hubballi rural tahasildar Prakash Nashi.

SWR celebrates Republic Day

Ajay Kumar Singh, general manager, South Western Railway, unfurled the tricolour and said the performance of SWR in the current year till the end of the third quarter is encouraging. “Gross earnings till end of December- 2019 are Rs. 4,341 crore that is Rs. 22 Crore more than that of last year. During this period, we have achieved loading of 27 Million Tonnes of freight which is 1% more than last year carried around 5 lakh passengers per day” he added.

Hubballi Division of SWR also celebrated the 71st Republic Day. Arvind Malkhede, divisional railway manager, unfurled the national flag and said that in the current financial year, up to December 2019, Hubballi Division has carried 264.23 lakh passengers. “The passenger earnings is Rs.277.62 crore which is 4.58% more in comparison to the corresponding period of last year” he said.

Patriotic fervour at Haveri

The 71th Republic Day was celebrated in the Haveri on Sunday. Deputy commissioner Krishna Bajpai unfurled the tricolour in the presence of district and taluk level officers and school children at Hosamani Siddappa District Stadium. DC said both Union and state governments are implementing several welfare schemes for the citizens while district administration is taking efforts to take such schemes to genuine beneficiaries.

Title: TDP to skip crucial assembly session
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

AMARAVATI: As the government is set to pass a resolution to abolish the legislative council, TDP has decided to boycott the assembly session on Monday.

TDP has only 21 MLAs in the 175-member assembly. The party wants to stay away from the session to show that the resolution to abolish the council was taken in the absence of the opposition.

The decision to stay away from the crucial session was taken at TDP legislature party meeting held in the party state office here on Sunday. Led by opposition leader Chandrababu Naidu , the meeting discussed the strategy to take on the government.

Curiously, at least six MLCs stayed away from the session which was convened to keep the folk together. Although all those abstained from the meeting had conveyed their inability to attend the session on personal and health grounds, it triggered panic in opposition circles in the wake of YSRC’s alleged attempts to poach some of the MLCs ahead of the Monday’s session.

Sources said MLCs Satrucharla Vijayaramaraju, KE Prabhakar, Gali Saraswathi, Tippe Swamy, AS Ramakrishna, Dokka Manikyavaraprasad abstained from the meeting.

While Manikyavaprasad had sent his resignation letter Naidu, Vijayaramaraju cited health grounds for his absence. Saraswathi could not attend as it was her husband and former minister Gali Muddukrishnama Naidu’s death anniversary. KE Prabhakar said he could not attend the meeting as he had to attend a ceremony in the family. Similarly, Tippe Swamy had a wedding in the family to attend. Dr AS Ramakrishna is in the US. As many as 23 MLCs of the total 32 attended the Sunday’s meeting.

While Pothula Sunitha, Sivanatha Reddy have parted ways with TDP, Samanthakamani could not reach party office due to delay in journey. She had also not attended Wednesday’s council session.

Absence of the MLCs is not going to play a big role in the current situation unless the government decides to reconvene the council which was indefinitely adjourned by the chairman on Wednesday.

Speaking to media after the TDLP meeting, MLC Bachula Arjunudu said the party has decided not to attend the session as there was no provision to discuss developments in the council in the assembly.

“YSRC is going ahead with unilateral decisions. They are going to move the resolution to abolish the council after failing to woo us,” said Arjunudu. He said there was no point in attending the session where there was no respect for the opposition.

TDP office staff displayed some visuals from films-Mohammed Bin Tughlaq and 23 Raaju Pulakesi at the TDLP meeting to show how the erstwhile kings ruined their empires with anti-people decisions.

Title: Erode: Pastors, priest, imam celebrate Republic Day at mosque
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

COIMBATORE: People from different faiths celebrated the Republic Day by unfurling the tricolor at Al Hidayath Sunnath Jamaath masjid at Nambiyur in Erode district on Sunday.

While Rasheed Ali from the mosque presided over the function, pastors David Raja, Andrews and Jebasteen, Nambiyur Ishwar temple trustee Rathinasami and president of Nambiyur traders’ association Lingaraj participated in the celebration.

All participated in their religious attire to emphasis religious harmony. Over 100 people participated in the celebrations.

Namakkal district collector K Megraj hoisted the flag at the district playground on Sunday. He distributed welfare schemes worth Rs 1.88 crores to 375 beneficiaries. He also distributed police medals to 43 police officials and certificates to 39 police officials for their meritorious service.

Salem district collector CA Raman hoisted the flag at the district playground. He distributed welfare schemes worth Rs 2.14 crore to 430 beneficiaries. He also distributed police medals to 108 police officials, honoured 10 ex-army men and four schools that performed well in the distsrict.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Future of legislative council likely to come up for debate
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy

VIJAYAWADA: All eyes are on Monday’s cabinet meeting and the subsequent assembly session, where a decision on abolishing the legislative council is likely to be the main agenda.

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy gave enough indications in the assembly on Thursday on abolishing it, after council chairman MA Shariff referred the capital decentralization and CRDA repeal bills to the select committee. Jagan, during his speech, had said that there is no need to continue the legislative council if it fails to follow the constitution and functions with political motives, dropping enough indications that he would make a move to abolish the council. Interestingly, a draft resolution for the same was reportedly kept ready even before the special assembly session commenced on January 20.

While the legislative council was adjourned sine die on Thursday, the assembly too was adjourned to meet again on Monday. The chief minister has also called for a cabinet meeting before the commencement of the session after the weekend break. There is every chance that the resolution to abolish the council might be put up during Monday’s assembly session.

Meanwhile, talks are reportedly being held among the MLCs to save the council from dissolution threat. Some MLCs are holding consultations to bring in a split in the TDP ranks and stay neutral to avoid conflict with the government. More than a dozen MLCs have their term ending in June 2021 and an equal number in March 2022, besides a few whose terms end in 2023-24.

A TDP MLC, Pothula Suneetha, has already crossed the fence and met the chief minister. Sources said there are at least a dozen MLCs from the TDP who are ready to differ with the party leadership and stay as a separate group. The BJP and the Progressive Democratic Front members have already hinted at staying away from voting on the government bills, thus giving an edge to the ruling party. If all these efforts succeed, the government may differ on tabling the bill to repeal the council.

Title: Suspects manipulated answer sheets in moving car; TNPSC staff among two more held
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: With the help of an employee from the Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission ( TNPSC ) scamsters manipulated answers scripts of 52 candidates who appeared for Group IV exam in a moving vehicle on the intervening night of September 1 and 2, the CBCID said in a release on Sunday.

Two more people including TNPSC employee H Omkanthan were arrested on Sunday, taking the total people arrested in the scam to nine since probe began on Friday.

Omkanthan came in contact with broker Jayakumar of Mogappair through an agent named Palani last year, a release from the CBCID said. After striking a deal, Jayakumar had asked Omkanthan to select Keelakarai and Rameswaram examination centres for exam duty, the release said. Jayakumar reached the place a day earlier, and after collecting cash from the candidates, he gave them the special pens with vanishing ink to write the exam with.

Jayakumar followed the van ferrying answer scripts to Chennai, for which Omkanthan was one of the escorts, in a car. When the van was stopped around 10.30pm for dinner near Sivaganga, Omkanthan took Manickavel (other escort), the van’s driver and a policeman guarding the vehicle to a restaurant on the other side of the road after parking the vehicle.

Omkanthan sat others in the restaurant and handed over the keys to the answer sheets locker to Jayakumar. Jayakumar opened the van, took the bundles out and made changes in the car all night while following the van. The answer sheets were put back in place when the van was stopped for tea near Vikravandi around 5.30am.

Police said the main suspect, Jayakumar, is still absconding, and police teams are searching for him.

Title: TNPSC aspirants want previous exams probed
Content:
TNPSC

CHENNAI: After the busting of a major scam in the Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission’s Group IV exam, many candidates said such malpractices have been going on for years and demanded that earlier exams conducted by the commission be investigated.On Friday, TNPSC suspended 99 candidates for life for resorting to malpractices in the Group IV exam held on September 1, 2019, after finding that answer sheets of 52 candidates who appeared from Rameswaram and Keelakarai centres in Ramanathapuram district were shaded after the exam. Agents supplied candidates pens with special ink which would disappear after a few hours to enable them to shade correct responses in OMR sheets later. Of 52 candidates, 39 ranked within the top 100.In the 2017 Group II-A exam, some candidates alleged, the topper answered 191 of 200 questions correctly and got 286.5 out of 300 marks, appearing from a centre in Ramanathapuram district. A few other toppers also wrote from Rameswaram and Keelakarai, they alleged.Karthikeyan, who has been preparing for competitive exams for last three years, said such malpractices prevented genuine candidates from getting jobs. “I narrowly missed appointment as the candidates with same marks got preference. I am a post-graduate and I cannot make any more attempts to enter government service...,” he said.Radian IAS Academy founder R Rajaboopathy said the scam was busted because the agents tried to be too smart. “Nearly 40 toppers from just two centres is impossible. Had they guessed the cut-off marks and given just above the cut-off marks the scam would have gone unnoticed,” he said.He said scamsters were targeting recruitment based only on exams like Group IV and Group II-A. “By introducing multiple stage exams and strengthening security at exam centres, such scams can be prevented.”U Sivabalan, academic head (TNPSC exams), Shankar IAS Academy , said many previous exams could have also been manipulated. “TNPSC should release names of the 99 candidates and should probe previous exams for malpractices. The racket could have influenced even Group I, Group II exams (multiple stage exams). It should consider moving from OMR sheets to online tests to prevent scams.”

Title: Away from Rajpath, Shaheen Bagh ‘celebrates the Republic’
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Tens of thousands of anti-CAA protesters assembled at Shaheen Bagh from midnight for a daylong celebration of ... Read More

NEW DELHI: While the Republic Day parade was on at Rajpath on Sunday morning, a different sort of celebration of the Republic was underway at Shaheen Bagh . Tens of thousands gathered at the now well-known protest site in southeast Delhi, where a trio of “Shaheen Bagh dadis” (grandmoms) unfurled the tricolour.

The organisers said the trio was accompanied by the mothers of former Hyderabad Central University scholar Rohith Vemula (Radhika) and missing JNU student Najeeb (Fatima Nafees), who unfurled the national flag together to a rapturous applause, followed by songs of celebration and patriotism which continued through the day.

Locals in the area, who have been at the forefront of the protest considered the heart of Delhi’s dissent against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC), claimed that over a lakh people came from across the city and outside to celebrate India’s Constitution on Sunday. The site resembled a sea of orange, white and green as the protesters waved the tricolour while fresh paintings, graffiti and street art around the national flag came up at the site.

Around 10 pm, actress Swara Bhasker visited the protest site and hit out at the central government for creating a negative image about the women protesting there. Also present were former JNU student Umar Khalid and Vadgam assembly constituency (in Gujarat) MLA Jignesh Mevani.

“Jahan dekho, tiranga lehra raha hai. Jahan dekho, India likha hai. Shaheen Bagh ke dil mein India hai. Pure desh ko dikh raha hai, aapko nahi dikh raha? (Wherever you see, there’s a tricolour waving. Wherever you look, there is India written. India is in Shaheen Bagh’s heart. The whole country can see that, so why can’t you?” said Bhasker, addressing the crowd in the evening.

Republic Day celebrations at Shaheen Bagh had begun at midnight itself, when thousands gathered for a mass reading of the preamble . This was followed by performances by artistes, street play troupes and music groups which continued late into the night. The tricolour was unfurled around 11am. While the Shahaan Bagh protest has been going on for over a month now, the organisers described Sunday as the most important day of the protest.

“We’ve tried to send a loud and clear message to the government that the Constitution is above all and on a day when it came into effect, what better way to celebrate the Constitution than to oppose CAA and NRC?” asked Irfan Ansari, a Shaheen Bagh local. Sporting an anti-CAA and NRC cap, Ansari said that just like the government which is adamant on not taking the back the Act, people of Shaheen Bagh will also continue to “respect” the ideals of the Constitution.

“This is not a communal issue, but it is far bigger than that. We will not tolerate divisive politics and over 1 lakh people came here this morning. This is a sign of unity and that everyone is willing to fight for each other,” said Ansari.

Naeemuddin, another local present at the site said the occasion, which is a reason to celebrate the Constitution and the fact that it was a public holiday attracted people from all parts of the city.

“There were at least 1-1.5 lakh people in the morning alone and celebrations continued till late at night. People are singing songs, carrying banners or simply coming here to stand in solidarity with each other,” said Naeemuddin.

Shahid Hussain, who came to Shaheen Bagh from Usmanpur said the occasion felt like a celebration and not a protest, which has been the objective of the people. “A lot of misinformation is being spread that people here are being paid to come here or that this protest is about a particular community. People from all across the city are coming here and we are seeing all religions and communities represented. The fight is to save our constitution and the rights of every Indian,” said Hussain.

The protesters also asserted that attempts being made to politicise the Shaheen Bagh agitation were likely to fail. On Saturday, Union home minister Amit Shah had asked people to “press the lotus button (during voting in Delhi assembly polls) so hard it makes the Shaheen Bagh protesters run away on the very evening of February 8”.

“The attempts to gain political mileage from the protests are wrong and people are not deterred by such accusations. Those who come to Shaheen Bagh know the ground reality and these numbers will only continue to grow,” said Ejaj.

Title: 17 TDP MLAs ready to jump ship, but CM Y S Jaganmohan Reddy against malpractices: Sajjala Ramakrishna Reddy
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy

AMARAVATI: Condemning speculation about horse trading , Sajjala Ramakrishna Reddy, advisor to chief minister, said YSRC does not need to poach MLAs from TDP. He said chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy will neither encourage nor indulge in unethical practices. He said that TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu was a malicious campaign on the issue as he is worried about the fate of his son once the council is dissolved.

Speaking to media here on Sunday, Sajjala said about 17 TDP MLAs were in touch with them and ready to switch sides. He said they could not do so as the chief minister was against such practices. “If MLAs are so eager, shall we need to tell about the anxiety of MLCs. However, we are not ready to take anyone into party for the sake of politics,” said Sajjala.

He said the assembly was adjourned for three days only to allow the people to debate the issue of TDP members’ attitude in the legislative council. He said TDP misused the council to stall the bills. He said that stalling the bills in the council by any means was nothing but acting against the mandate given by the people as the government had secured 86% of the seats in the assembly.

“TDP chief stooped so low by influencing the council chairman by sitting in the gallery. How long could they stop the bills with such practice?” asked Sajjala. He dismissed TDP’s claims about Naidu having a telephonic conversation with Union home minister Amit Shah to stall the abolition of the legislative council.

“Naidu criticised both Shah and prime minister Narendra Modi with vulgar language in the past. Naidu is just trying to fool his MLCs from parting ways,” said Sajjala.

Municipal administration minister Botcha Satyanarayana said the assembly would take a final call on the dissolution of the council on Monday. He said that the CM is of the view that people would decide whether the council had to be abolished. He wondered that vernacular media, which supported the council abolishment when NTR took the call, is spewing venom on Jagan for the same decision. “It is evident that council chairman has violated the rules and sent the bill to select committee. We are not influencing the MLCs and seeking their support,” said Botcha.

Title: UGC adds 1,000 ‘quality academic journals’ to its list
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

UGC’s ‘Consortium of Academic and Research Ethics (Care)’ has so far added around 1,000 Indian academic journa... Read More

COIMBATORE: The University Grants Commission (UGC)’s ‘ Consortium of Academic and Research Ethics (Care)’ has so far added around 1,000 Indian academic journals to its list since it was formed last November, and the list is growing, said Bhushan Patwardhan, vice-chairman of UGC. He said the UGC was seeking to add more ‘credible Indian journals’ to its list under Care.

Patwardhan, who was in the city recently, said Care has stakeholders from across fields such as statutory bodies, academies and councils to review the journals every quarter.

Last November, the UGC had formed Care to ‘prepare a list of credible quality journals’ in the fields of social sciences, humanities, languages, arts, culture, Indian knowledge systems etc. The move came after bogus journals, predatory and paid academic journals started mushrooming across the country.

“Studies showed that 88% of journals in the UGC approved list were dubious. India has earned a very bad reputation because of this in the past 15 years. So we wanted to create a credible database of reputed journals to stop the practice of pay and publish,” he said.

Pointing out that the consortium has bodies such as the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research , the Indian Council of Medical Research and the Indian Council of Social Science Research, he said the members together decide which journals are good to be included in the list.

He said the databases such as Scopus and Web of Science could not be followed blindly in the process, as there were many journals in Indian languages and Indian knowledge systems which cannot go into those databases. “For that we need to have system like Care,” he said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Sugarcane farmers yet to get Centre’s share of MSP
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose

TIRUPUR: Many farmers in the district who had supplied sugarcane to Amaravathi cooperative sugar mill last season are yet to receive the Centre’s share of the minimum support price.

The sugar mill at Krishna Nagar in Madathukulam crushed 1.28 lakh tonnes of sugarcane grown in Tirupur, Dindigul and Erode districts last season after it had halted production for the previous two seasons due to low yield of the crop.

“The MSP was fixed at Rs 2,750 per tonne. While the state government had paid its share of Rs 2,612.5, the centre is yet to disburse its share of Rs 137.5 to some farmers,” said A Bala Thandapani, district joint secretary of the Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam, which is affiliated to AIKS. The sugar mill had procured 75,000 tonnes of sugarcane from farmers in Tirupur district , he added.

“While the Centre had transferred the amount for around 50,000 tonnes of sugarcane that were crushed till July last through the direct transfer method, the remaining amount is yet to be disbursed,” he said, adding that farmers should get the money within two weeks once they supplied the crop.

He also urged the state government to ensure that the crusher in the sugar mill is in good condition as last season it needed to be stopped for 28 days due to poor maintenance. tnn

Title: Tamil Nadu: Disabled people yet to get revised Rs 2,000 monthly aid
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Last year, the state government announced that it would increase the monthly pension for disabled people from Rs 1,000 to Rs 2,000 and provide motorised wheelchairs to those with severe locomotor disabilities . Neither of the promises has seen the light of the day.

Andal Kumaran, a 62-year-old Saidapet resident who has muscular dystrophy, is struggling to avail of both. Andal says the earlier pension of Rs 1,000 she continues to receive is insufficient. “The amount is not enough. I had also written to the disabled welfare department to provide me a wheelchair but no progress has been made so far,” she said. Same is the case with 82-year-old K S Sreenivasan of Guindy , who has not received either of the benefits.

The state had announced that it would increase the monthly disability allowance from Rs 1,000 to Rs 2,000, half of which will be given to a relative or caretaker of the person. However, the state has only made a list of 800 beneficiaries who can avail this assistance.

“When I went to the local authorities they turned me away saying my name is not on the list,” said Sreenivasan. “I have written to every authority concerned about my condition. I have also explained that I am in desperate need of the assistance. But they haven’t done anything so far.”

The state provides the monthly welfare assistance to nearly one lakh disabled people across the state through the department for welfare of the differently abled, but beneficiaries have on several occasions complained that they don’t receive it on time.

In 2017, the government said it would provide 1,000 motorised wheelchairs to those in need but less than 200 people have received it, and some of it were damaged. The Spinal Injured Persons Association had written to the department, requesting them to arrange service centres to repair the faulty wheelchairs. “In one instance, a beneficiary toppled and suffered multiple fractures and had to be admitted at CMC Vellore. We have received a number of complaints on (faulty) parts... We request you to set up service centres,” the letter read.

Officials from the department said they were waiting for fund sanctions from the government to provide more wheelchairs. “We have prepared a new list of beneficiaries and will be providing them the revised pension amount shortly,” said an official.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Sugarcane farmers yet to get Centre’s share of MSP
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose

TIRUPUR: Many farmers in the district who had supplied sugarcane to Amaravathi cooperative sugar mill last season are yet to receive the Centre’s share of the minimum support price.

The sugar mill at Krishna Nagar in Madathukulam crushed 1.28 lakh tonnes of sugarcane grown in Tirupur, Dindigul and Erode districts last season after it had halted production for the previous two seasons due to low yield of the crop.

“The MSP was fixed at Rs 2,750 per tonne. While the state government had paid its share of Rs 2,612.5, the centre is yet to disburse its share of Rs 137.5 to some farmers,” said A Bala Thandapani, district joint secretary of the Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam, which is affiliated to AIKS. The sugar mill had procured 75,000 tonnes of sugarcane from farmers in Tirupur district , he added.

Title: Water innovators leading the way
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

TOI brings to you some unique startups participating in INK@WASH, a platform to promote innovations in waste & sanitation, organised by ASCI in association with the state and central governments on January 30 and 31.

Name: Clean Water

Founder: Priyanshu Kumath

Location: Indore

Objective: Creating floating islands with wetland plants on bases made from recycled plastic, wood and other metals, to restore and beautify water bodies

Impact: About 10 lakes either rejuvenated or prepared for ecologically restoration through the use of 14 types of floating islands across Indore, Bengaluru etc. Use even on the Sabarmati River Front

Road Ahead: To reach millions of lakes across India by setting up a distributor network that can approach local governments to implement these floating islands.

Water bodies across the country are drying up and left neglected. Only one percent of them have been restored so far. We want to fill this gap by not only restoring the lakes and but also the entire ecology and biodiversity around them. Priyanshu Kumath

Name: Absolute water Pvt Ltd

Founders: Sunil Singhal and Smita Singhal

Location: Delhi

Objective: Creating bio-filters using earthworms, wooden chips, stones and pebbles, to disinfect sewerage water and make it usable for horticulture, agriculture and other industrial purposes.

Impact: More than 6,000 cubic metres of water treated through this process across 45 installations in Delhi, Ludhiana, Bengaluru, Hyderabad etc.

Road Ahead: Working with governments in Gurgaon, Punjab and other places to further the project.

Water shortage is increasing by the day in India. In such a situation, we are trying to extract as much water as we can from sewage. The process not only addresses water pollution- but also helps meet our water demand, in an organic way. Ankur Sawhney, techo-commercial manager

Name: SAHE

Founder: Kalpana Ramesh

Location: Hyderabad

Objective: Channelling rooftop rain water into the ground, through its rain water project. Roping in builders, large institutions and communities to conserve rain water.

Impact: Restoration of Kudikunta Lake, in Masjid Banda, by removing illegal inlets and making way for rainwater from rooftops of communities around the lake to follow into it. Similar modules set up on other campuses as well.

Road Ahead: Proposed to turn all parks in the city into rain water harvesting zones

There is an urgent need to recharge our groundwater while also blocking out channels that contaminate it. We intend to take our solution not just to big gated communities and offices, but also small groups and provide them with solutions that can help conserve rain water, the right way. Kalpana Ramesh

Name: Transwater Systems Pvt Ltd

Founder: Vikas Brahmavar

Location: Bengaluru

Objective: To make sewage water in commercial and residential establishment potable through a 11-stage treatment system called Boson White Water

Impact: Through its four installations in Bengaluru -- three malls, one IT park and one residential society -- treated 7,856 tankers-worth of water (each tanker carries 6,000 litres of water) that has been put back in use within the same premises.

Road Ahead: To expand to other tier 1 cities in south India by end of 2020

Our studies in Bengaluru has shown that every apartment complex generates anywhere between 30,000 to 3 lakh litres of water every day, which eventually flows into lakes. The quantity generated by malls and IT parks is equally high. If we can put this back in use, we can save a tremendous amount of fresh water. That’s our endeavour. Gowthaman Desingh, director (technical)

Title: Shaheen Bagh: CM & Shah in bitter war
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

New Delhi: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal went on the offensive on the Shaheen Bagh issue on Monday, accusing BJP of deliberately not getting the road opened. Addressing a press conference, the chief minister said: “BJP does not want to get the road — closed due to the protest — opened . Holding press conferences will not lead to improvement in law and order in Delhi. Law and order can improve with efforts. We can teach you how to work. We know how to work and they only know how to hold press conferences and do dirty politics.”

Kejriwal seemed to have overcome his initial hesitation in discussion the issue, faced with BJP’s aggressive campaigning. He said the road, affected by the protest against Citizenship Amendment Act, will be opened on February 9, a day after polling is held for the assembly elections. The closure is causing huge inconvenience to commuters.

It was last week after deputy CM Manish Sisodia said on a TV channel that he stands with the Shaheen Bagh protesters that BJP began attacking him and Kejriwal. Party spokesperson Sambit Patra called AAP an anti-Hindu party while Hari Nagar candidate Tajinder Singh Bagga said BJP stands with India and AAP with Shaheen Bagh protesters.

Union home minister Amit Shah escalated the attack on Monday by daring Kejriwal to clear his stand on the Shaheen Bagh protests and explain whether he was in favour of the protesters.

Later, on Twitter, Kejriwal responded to Shah who had also sought his stand on JNU student Sharjeel Imam, who has been booked for his speeches. “Sharjeel talked about cutting off Assam from the country. This is serious. You are the home minister of the country. Your statement is low level of politics. It is your responsibility to get him arrested. Two days have passed since he made the remarks. Why are you not arresting him? What is your helplessness? Or do you have to do more dirtier politics?” Kejriwal asked on Twitter.

“I am disappointed with the dirty politics of BJP on the issue,” he said at the press conference. “The road is closed and it is causing inconvenience to a large number of people. School children and ambulances are facing obstruction. Travelling (through Kalindi Kunj) that usually took 30-40 minutes is taking two-and-a-half to three hours. “I can give it in writing that...the road will open on February 9.”

The chief minister said he had repeatedly observed that Constitution guarantees the right to protest to every citizen but it should not result in inconvenience to the common man. “Why is the BJP led central government, which is responsible for law and order, not solving this problem,” asked Kejriwal. He said that instead of holding a press conference, union minister Ravi Shankar Prasad should have visited Shaheen Bagh and talked to the protesters to get the road opened. He urged Shah and other BJP leaders to also visit Shaheen Bagh and do the job.

Title: VMC brightens Vijayawada walls in bid to tackle public urination
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

A team of 10 students from the School of Planning and Architecture, Vijayawada has painted a wall along Gopala... Read More

VIJAYAWADA: In a novel initiative, the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) is transforming walls and other spaces in the city through paintings to discourage urination in public places. The civic body, which had painted walls with a combined length of around 10 km in 2018, has now taken up the strategy to improve its ranking in Swachh Survekshan-2020. VMC authorities have roped in students of various educational institutions to assist with painting the walls.

A team of 10 students from the School of Planning and Architecture, Vijayawada has painted a wall along Gopala Reddy Road to prevent public urination. The painting portrays a sanitation worker sweeping the roads also marks the prominent places in the city in the background and aims to explain to residents the Swachh initiatives undertaken by the civic body.

The VMC, meanwhile, is monitoring the street art created by the students. Assistant city planner at the VMC, Avala Ajay Kumar said, “This is not the first time that the VMC is utilising the services of students. Hundreds of students voluntarily painted the walls on both sides of Bandar Road during the Krishna Pushkarams in 2016. They had also played a key role in making the city India’s cleanest big city in 2018. So, we have decided to work along with them in making the city clean and beautiful,” he said.

“We have started painting scenes and messages at walls and spots adjacent to garbage bins to check urination in public places, and have noticed a significant fall in the trend,” the city planner said, adding that students of various city colleges have given their consent to paint the walls.

The School of Planning and Architecture developed the conceptual paintings, Ajay Kumar said.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Man dies in clash between two groups
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: A 48-year-old man succumbed to injuries in a clash between two groups at Nernipalli village under V Kota mandal in Chittoor district on Sunday. The deceased was identified as Sheik Abdul Yukthiyar.

According to V Kota circle inspector, Sheik Abdul Yukthiyar and his two sons worked as welders. Two days ago, the three were called by one Ameerjan of Nernipalli village for carrying out welding work. The work was completed within a day and Yukthiyar and his sons received Rs 4,000 upon completion.

On Sunday, Ameerjan who had engaged Yukthiyar and his sons, alleged that the welding work was faulty and demanded they return Rs 2,000.

Yukthiyar and his sons and Ameerjan and some persons supporting him had a heated altercation on the issue and in a clash between both groups, the 48-year-old Yukthiyar, who sustained blows in the attack, collapsed. He was rushed to a nearby government hospital immediately, where doctors declared him brought dead.

V Kota police registered a case following a complaint lodged by family members of the deceased and sent the body for post-mortem.

Police have suspects into custody and are carrying out an investigation.

Title: Delhi: Near Jamia Millia Islamia, a poetic celebration of Constitution through the night
Content:
While traffic movement remained functional on one side of the road, the other carriageway was blocked by prote... Read More

NEW DELHI: Not far from Shaheen Bagh , the epicentre of anti-CAA protests in Delhi, the streets of Jamia were buzzing with action. Thousands of students from Jamia Millia Islamia , DU and JNU came out on the roads late into the night on Saturday and stayed through Sunday to “celebrate the Constitution”.With poetry and songs, the protesters made their dissent heard. While traffic movement remained functional on one side of the road, the other carriageway was blocked, first by those painting fresh graffiti on the walls and, then, by the thousands who gathered to celebrate Republic Day .Just like at Shaheen Bagh, the students were joined by women and children as they waved the tricolour on the streets. Locals said the numbers swelled in the afternoon. A tricolour was hoisted in the area by Jamia Millia Students’ Association, which was followed by the singing of the national anthem and the anthem of Jamia Millia Islamia.“It’s all about being together and celebrating the idea of being Indian. This protest is not limited to the students alone, as residents from Jamia Nagar, Okhla and New Friends Colony are coming in huge numbers every day,” said Shoaib Choudhary, one such protester.Chowdhary said he stayed at the protest site till 4am on Sunday, only to come back after a few hours. “Just like me, several others decided to celebrate Republic Day out on the streets. This is an important day for everyone and for the movement against CAA and NRC. The new law is against the Constitution in many ways and one cannot enact it and celebrate the Constitution at the same time,” Chowdhary claimed.As the people enjoyed street performances and plays through the day, there were renditions of poetry and songs of “dissent” at Gulmohar Avenue in Jamia Nagar. A mix of musicians and poets, entertained the people as they spoke out against CAA and NRC.Mohammad Aurangzeb, an engineering student who had come from Patna to take part in the protests, said people were not losing hope. “I’ve been in Delhi for a few days now and I know these protesters are not going anywhere, judging by the sheer numbers. Republic Day is an even more special occasion, as it sends a clear message that the country is governed by the Constitution and we will not tolerate any attempt to break its secular fabric,” Aurangzeb said.In the evening, the streets also saw a number of candlelight and tiranga marches, covering Zakir Nagar, Jamia Nagar and Shaheen Bagh.Wasil, who recently graduated from Jamia Millia Islamia and is a resident of Okhla, claimed that people were smart and would vote only for development in the upcoming assembly polls despite efforts by some politicians to polarise opinion.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Minor girl raped, hunt on to nab accused
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

Title: Bhim Army chief detained in Hyderabad ahead of anti-CAA protest meet
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad

HYDERABAD: Anticipating that he may stage a rally, Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad was taken into preventive custody while he was on the way to a protest meeting at Mehdipatnam on Sunday evening. Azad was in the city to participate in protest meetings against CAA-NRC-NPR.

Hyderabad police brass said a large number of Azad’s followers gathered at a hotel, where he was camping. He was supposed to reach Crystal Garden, Mehdipatnam, where he was planning to participate in Republic Day celebrations organised by All India Dalit, Muslim, Adivasi Progressive Front. Police, who were already tailing him, took him into custody the moment he stepped out of the hotel near Nampally around 6.30pm.

“We had information that Azad and others were planning to take out a rally. Publicity was given widely on social media and also among organisers of the event that a rally will be taken out. Since police had not given any permission for the rally, Azad was taken into prevention custody,’’ a senior Hyderabad police officer told TOI. He was likely to be released later in the night, sources said.

Apart from Azad, other protesters, who were with him at the hotel and Crystal Garden, were also taken into custody. On learning that Azad was taken to the Habeeb Nagar police station, protesters started to gather outside the police station. Later, Azad was shifted to the Bolarum police station, while other protesters were sent to Goshamahal grounds.

Earlier, Azad participated in a protest programme on Tata Institute of Social Sciences (TISS) campus at Abdullapurmet, which was organized to focus on student issues as well as Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA).

He reached the campus by 11.20am and took part in an interactive session, where the main focus was on sexual harassment at educational institutions and how it should be dealt, especially when there was little help from university administration and police.

“If the police and administration are not addressing sexual harassment cases, approach women and child welfare department,” Azad said, adding along with protest it was also important to bring external pressure to get justice. He was at TISS campus till 1.30pm.

Azad also took to Twitter and alleged that police personnel not only made female students sit at the station the whole night, but also mistreated them.

“Insulting our sisters will not be tolerated,” tweeted Azad from TISS campus demanding the Rachakonda police to reach the institute and explain why female students were treated badly and made to sit at the station.

He also accompanied the students along with his lawyer to Adibatla police station to find out the status about sexual harassment cases, eight of them filed by TISS students in the current academic year. He left the station around 3pm,

“Eighty-three students were at the police station the whole night yesterday to file a complaint against molesters. The FIR copy was given at 4pm today, that too after intervention of Azad,” said Shashank, a student of TISS, said.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Round Table to set up infrastructure in government schools
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

GUNTUR: President of the state wing of Round Table International (RTI) Umesh Kapadia said on Sunday the organisation has launched an initiative to build infrastructure in government schools in the state. Kapadia laid the foundation stone for the construction of toilets in the mandal parishad primary school in Gorantla. The project is being funded by Round Table Guntur (RTG-86).

Addressing students on the occasion, Kapadia said many young entrepreneurs and business leaders have joined the organised to serve society. “It is a way of giving back to society. It is heartening that many young business leaders are liberally spending on charity works from their pockets,” he said. Kapadia praised RTG-86 for extending financial support to key projects.

RTG-86 president Raavi Balakrishna said members of the organisation were keen to be part of the state government’s ‘Nadu-Nedu’ programme that was launched to revamp infrastructure in the public schools. The project, Balakrishna said, would help children from underprivileged sections, especially girls, attend schools. The organisation has also decided to organise sports meets for children in government schools, he said. He said they would also provide sports kits to talented players to enable them to participate at state and national-level meets.

Chairman of Ladies Circle, R Lakshmipraya , said they were encouraging members to play an active role in funding construction of toilets in government schools as female students suffered from the absence of clean washrooms. Washrooms with running water would also help bring down the dropout rate in government schools, she said.

Convener of RTG projects Lanka Kranti Sekhar said they were lining up more programmes to improve infrastructure in public schools.

Title: Coin crisis: TTD godown to be free, 85 tonne coins set for SAIL
Content:
The richest temple administration in the country had disposed of nearly 90,000 bags of coins of various denomi... Read More

TIRUPATI: The Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams ’ (TTD) coins conundrum is moving toward final resolution. It will be handing over the last batch of nearly 85 tonne of demonetised coins to Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL) in Salem in the first week of February for melting, freeing its godown that’s fast running out of space to store coin bags.The richest temple administration in the country had disposed of nearly 90,000 bags of coins of various denominations in October 2018 and mopped up Rs 30 crore.Though coins of denomination of 25 paise and below were demonetised by the Reserve Bank of India in July 2011, devotees continued to offer large quantities of such coins.Nationalised banks, which TTD used to transact with, continued to accept the demonetised coins until February 2014. But later they stopped accepting them, leading to piling up of huge stocks.When TTD first tried to exchange the demonetised coins at face value with the RBI, the central bank advised the TTD to approach the Union finance ministry to get the issue resolved.Following several parleys, the government mint at Mumbai, advised the TTD to get its demonetised coins disposed of by melting them with the help of SAIL’s steel plant at Salem in Tamil Nadu.On June 26, 2018, the TTD trust board accorded approval to dispose of the entire stocks of demonetised Indian coins through SAIL.Meanwhile on April 18, 2019, the Union finance ministry accorded permission to TTD to melt these coins at an already negotiated price of Rs 29,972 per metric tonne. As per the agreement between TTD and SAIL, the payment to be made to TTD will be adjusted towards supplies made to TTD by SAIL.In the first phase 40 tonnes will be disposed of. The remaining stock will be melted in the second phase a week later.

Title: History lies abandoned as ruins atop Kondaveedu hill cry out for preservation
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Guntur: About an hour’s drive from Guntur town lies Kondaveedu Hills with the historic Kondaveedu Fort and several ruins of temples and other structures. Abandoned structures of historical significance dot the area, but there is almost no preservation of these.

One of the problems lies in entering the area, which is a protected Reserve Forest, without permission from the forest department. Nor has the archaeology department taken up any initiative to preserve the structures, citing hurdles by the forest department.

Researchers to the area said they have uncovered previously undiscovered structures but their history remains undocumented in the absence of proper investigation, exploration and preservation by the archaeology department. While tourists to the Fort area have increased following the laying of a ghat road in 2019, less attention has been paid to the historically significant structures in the area. “All of Kondaveedu hill zone is a treasure trove of heritage structures. We need to take some urgent measures to protect such structures by denotifying the hill from the rest of the Reserve Forest,” said Kalli Sivareddy, historian and convener of the Kondaveedu Development Society.

Sivareddy added that in recent expeditions, he came across a Siva temple near Rudrapada Sikharam, the highest peak among the hills in thearea. The Rudrapada Sikharam is also known as Adam Shafi hill, named after the Sufi saint Adam Shafi. Muslims in the area believe the spot is the dargah of the saint and renovated the tank here, and use the space to hold festivals.

Near the Bollurmora Sri Venkateswara Swamy temple on hill housing the Fort lies two abandoned wells. For several years now, residents of villages around Kondaveedu Fort have organised a ‘brahmotsavam’ every year on April 27, yet the wells were left to neglect. One of the wells is known as ‘kanyakala baavi’ while the other is ‘jaddigala baavi’. According to historians, locals believe that celestial beings bathed in one of the wells, and named it ‘kanyakala baavi’. Two ‘kanyaka’ structures were also found nearby.

Further into the forest and on the hilltop is an abandoned temple with a mandapam and 16 pillars arranged in two rows. Historians are unsure yet if the temple is a Shaivite or Vaishnavite structure. “Further study is required to ascertain the history of the temple. It is believed to be a ‘yogi vemana mandapam’,” said Sivareddy.

Studies also point to the existence of a small barrage that connects two hills in the area. “It is high time that the government writes to the Union ministry of environment and forests to denotify the area from the Reserve Forest and preserve the historical structures here,” said Sivareddy.

Former director of the archaeology department Emani Sivanareddy said Kondaveedu could become the biggest heritage attraction in the state if efforts are made to preserve it.

Title: ‘Scandalous’ speech: DMK urges Tamil Nadu governor to act against minister
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

K C Karuppannan

CHENNAI: The DMK has written to Tamil Nadu governor Banwarilal Purohit seeking to get state environment minister K C Karuppannan dropped from the cabinet for his controversial speech, insinuating that the state government won’t allocate adequate funds for local bodies won by DMK.

In the memorandum sent to the governor on Sunday, DMK treasurer S Durai Murugan accused Karuppannan of making a “scandalous, irresponsible and divisive” speech at a public meeting in Erode on January 23. “I call upon you to exercise your power and demand resignation of K C Karupannan, failing which dismiss him from the council of ministers for breach of oath of office,” Durai Murugan said in the memorandum.

Addressing the gathering at MGR birth anniversary celebrations in Erode, Karuppannan had chided the public for voting for DMK in the civic body elections. “You have voted for DMK in Sathyamangalam panchayat union. What development will be there if the panchayat union chairman is from DMK. Only if we (state government) allot funds, there will be development. How will they provide you basic amenities if we don’t allot funds?” he asked. “If there is a DMK chairman, we will not allot funds. We will sanction lesser funds. You have made a mistake by not voting for ‘two leaves’ (AIADMK symbol),” he said. Karuppannan then went on to list the contributions of the AIADMK government in terms of basic amenities in the area and said he was saddened by the fact that even the community which was staunchly backing AIADMK did not vote for it this time. “At least in future, think well and vote for ‘two leaves’,” he said.

Durai Murugan said the minster’s speech was a direct threat to the people, to put them in hardship by restricting access to public funds merely because they did not choose to elect candidates from AIADMK.

In a damage control exercise, Karupannan told reporters in Andhiyur later on Saturday that his speech was misunderstood. “What I intended to say was that the ruling party can provide better amenities if the civic body chiefs were also from the same party,” he said.

Sathyamangalam panchayat union chairman from DMK shot back saying that if the government allotted insufficient funds, he will still provide better amenities by getting funds from DMK legislators under MLA funds.

Title: Needle in body: Madras high court seeks government response
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Madras high court has sought response from the state government on a plea moved by a woman seeking compensation and action against nurses and the doctor for leaving behind a broken needle in her body after child birth at a primary health centre (PHC) in Ramanathapuram district .

Petitioner Ramya, 22, a resident of Uchipuli and wife of Karthikeyan, said she was admitted to the local PHC on November 19 where she gave birth to a girl child through normal delivery. However, she suffered from a minor complication named episiotomy (surgical incision through vaginal wall during child birth) due to which she was bleeding even after being shifted to the ward. She said a doctor was not present during the delivery and it was the nurses who handled the situation. When the doctor arrived, she inquired about the bleeding but neither the doctor not the nurses responded properly.

Since she was bleeding continuously, she was referred to the government hospital at Ramanathapuram where the doctors noticed a broken needle inside her body in the X-ray. That was when she understood that the nurses while stitching the incision after performing episiotomy, had left behind a broken needle inside her body negligently. She was referred to the government Rajaji hospital in Madurai the same day and the needle was removed after a surgery on November 21. She stated that even after getting discharged she suffered from severe pain and once again had to get admitted at Ramanathapuram government hospital. Due to the negligent act of the nurses and doctor of Uchipuli PHC, she was put to great hardship after her child birth.

Hearing her plea for compensation and also action against the nurses and doctor of Uchipuli PHC, Justice S S Sundar sought a response from the government and adjourned the case to further date for hearing.

Title: Andhra Pradesh government plans 10,000 MW solar project
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

VIJAYAWADA: The state government is planning to set up a mega solar power project with an installed capacity of 10,000 MW in order to meet the increasing demand for power and to supply free, uninterrupted power to the agricultural sector.

Addressing employees of the energy department after Republic Day celebrations here on Sunday, energy secretary Nagulapalli Srikant said that the project will ensure an abundant supply of power to the agricultural sector.

The energy secretary noted that the number of agricultural connections in the state now stand at 18.1 lakh after the recent addition of 25,000 connections. The department is planning to increase the number of connections by another 25,000 in the current fiscal.

Srikant further said that the government is working on various options to optimise its power purchase cost with a mix of power from thermal, hydel and renewable energy sources.

The objective, the energy secretary said, is to make power cost-effective and to contribute to industrial, agricultural and economic growth and improve the living standards of consumers.

Despite severe financial constraints, the state government has allocated Rs 7,779 crore as subsidy for agriculture and aquaculture, said Srikant. The government has also strengthened human resource in the power sector by appointing 7,000 linemen and 175 assistant engineers.

Power utilities in the state have also saved Rs 500 crore through power purchase under open market bidding and Rs 180 crore in coal supply tenders. Srikant further noted that stage-V of Vijayawada Thermal Power Station and stage-II of SDSTPS at Krishnapatnam will be commissioned in 2020, adding 1,600 MW capacity.

The state government is prioritising energy efficiency and energy conservation, he added.

Title: Delhi: 9,435 trees to be cut for Dwarka Expressway, 400 go ‘missing’
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

The submission made before NGT stated that of the 9,035 trees now, 5,717 would be transplanted.

NEW DELHI: As many as 9,435 trees will have to be cut for the Dwarka Expressway project. Of these, 400 have already gone “missing”, a submission made by the principal chief conservator of forest (PCCF) to National Green Tribunal has revealed.

The report stated that an inspection carried out by the forest department staff revealed that at least 400 trees were buried under construction debris. A fine of Rs 2.4 crore was imposed on National Highways Authority of India, it added.

“Notices were issued to NHAI, its contractors and other agencies working adjacent to the site where the trees were found buried under the construction debris. After giving sufficient opportunities to all the parties concerned, the tree officer disposed of the matter with a direction to NHAI to pay Rs 2.4 crore for the missing trees,” the report stated.

To meet the compensatory plantation norms, PCCF Ishwar Singh said 90,350 saplings would have to be planted, for which 90.4 hectares of land had been identified. The report stated that 6.2 hectares at Aravalli Biodiversity Park, 5.5 hectares at Tughlakabad Biodiversity Park, 15 hectares along Yamuna floodplain and 63.6 hectares of land under DDA’s “green belt” had been identified. The entire 90.4 hectares of land belongs to DDA.

“This much area of the land bank submitted by NHAI is found suitable and sufficient to accommodate 90,350 saplings, fulfilling the criteria as mandated under the Delhi Presevation of Trees Act,” the report stated.

The submission made before the tribunal also stated that of the 9,035 trees now, 5,717 would be transplanted. Rules mandate at least 80% of the trees to be transplanted from the construction site. The agency concerned also needs to ensure that at least 80% of the trees transplanted survive the process after a year.

Title: ‘Bringing the govt closer to people’
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Vijayawada: The 71st Republic Day celebrations in the city were held at the Indira Gandhi Municipal Stadium. Governor Biswabhusan Harichandan unfurled the tri-colour and spoke on the welfare activities initiated by the government and explained the motive behind the plan to have three capitals for the state.

“Decentralisation will bring people closer to the government and arrest tendencies that arise out of frustration due to unequal opportunities and considerations of wealth. The development of all regions and all sections of people, irrespective of caste, creed, region, religion and party affiliation is the promise of the government and it is going ahead in this direction,” the governor said.The governor reaffirmed the state’s commitment to the welfare of the poor and the backward classes. Schemes under Navaratnalu are geared towards this as is the village and ward secretariat system, which will fine-tune administration.

The Polavaram project will be completed by 2021, the governor said, and a 7.2 lakh-acre ayacut will be built across Krishna, Guntur and the Godavari districts.

The governor also spoke about the Disha Act, Amma Vodi scheme and village volunteers.

Title: Citizen group suggests local ring rail service
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Bengaluru: With the suburban rail project delayed, a citizen group suggested ring rail services using the existing 46km track with 10 stations connecting four hubs: Bengaluru City, Byappanahalli , Yelahanka and Yeshwantpur .

Rajkumar Duggar, founder of Citizens for Citizens (C4C), said: “C4C has worked out a conceptual design to implement local trains along the existing ring rail which works as a stop-gap arrangement till the suburban train system begins functioning. It will take more than six years to implement a dedicated suburban rail system.”

He suggested deploying Demu/Memu trains since they can reverse easily and also attain high speed.” said Duggar.

Rail activist Sanjeev Dyamannavar said the service can be operated at lower frequencies but constraints like a single line between Byappanahalli-Channasandra, lack of automatic signalling system, change of platforms at KSR Bengaluru City station and the track problem between Yeswantpur and Lottegollahalli have to be resolved.

But Bengaluru divisional railway manager Ashok Kumar Verma said: “It’s not feasible to have a ring railway system in the city since it’s not designed for it. Further, like suburban rail, we will need to get approvals and it will take more or less the same time. Re-modelling of existing infrastructure will be more challenging.”

Title: Karnataka: Education department plans karate classes for govt school girls, boys
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

BENGALURU: The education department plans to introduce karate training in government schools from the next academic year to help students learn self-defence techniques. As a first step, the department wants to introduce it in a few thousand schools to gauge its success before scaling it up.

The initiative was mooted after primary and secondary education minister S Suresh Kumar received a call from Chikkamagaluru student Suchita during his monthly phone-in programme, Samvedana. She requested for self-defence classes “to help students like her feel safe”. The department intends to start classes at least in some schools, starting with ones in remote regions, in the upcoming academic year. The classes will be for both boys and girls.

However, the challenge before the department is how to fund recruitment of teachers. At its recent meeting with not-for-profits and corporates seeking public-private partnership in strengthening government schools, it put forward a proposal of Rs 6.4 crore to start karate classes in 4,000 schools. “We are yet to finalise the modalities for introducing the classes; we have to identify schools, teachers and class timings. We are also looking at various fund options for the programme,” said KG Jagadeesha, commissioner, department of public instruction.

The move is part of the safety measures the department is planning to extend to its schools. Installing CCTVs in all its 48,000 schools, which will cost Rs 242 crore, is the other proposal.

“Introducing karate is a great initiative. Apart from the fact that it will improve self-defence, karate will also boost students’ concentration and strength. Instead of restricting it to a 12-hour session (as was done for class 9 students till last year), the department should make it an annual programme and introduce it at a younger age,” said HC Sowbhagya, physical education teacher at Government Urdu High School , DJ Halli.

Title: Suffering from sleep apnea? Check fat in your tongue
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A 45-year-old man with acute sleep apnea recently had the lymphoid tissues at the base of his tongue removed at a private hospital in Bengaluru. Though he had trouble speaking for a couple of days, his speech gradually improved. What also got better was his sleep, with fewer symptoms of sleep apnea.

What has sleep got to do with the tongue? A lot. Not just the tongue, but several tissues of mouth cavity can affect sleep by blocking airways, resulting in obstructive sleep apnea. A sleep disorder, OSA causes not just snoring, but also repeatedly interrupts breathing which stops and restarts.

Recently, researchers from the Perelman School of Medicine at University of Pennsylvania discovered that improvements in sleep apnea symptoms appear to be linked to reduction of fat in one unexpected body part, the tongue.

Bengaluru doctors say the study, recently published in the American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, vindicates their treatment protocol for sleep-related issues.

Dr Shantanu Tandon, ENT, sleep apnea and endoscopic surgeon, Sakra World Hospital, said there are several factors in the neck area and mouth cavity that can lead to sleep apnea.

“Sleep endoscopy helps in dynamic evaluation and visual evaluation of the upper airway, where we see the severity, pattern, location of the collapse of the palate, tongue base and tonsils,” said Dr Tandon, who sees over 50-60 cases of sleep-related issues every month.

According to Dr Tandon, the base of the tongue becoming floppy and sagging because of accumulated muscle tissue is rare compared to obstruction to sleep caused by tonsils, palette as well as neck fat. “If the obstruction is caused by tongue muscle or a lymphoid tissue, it’s reduced by a procedure called ‘radio frequency associated tongue-base reduction’,” the doctor added.

Dr Vivek Anand Padegal, director, pulmonology, Fortis Hospital, says the study’s finding that the dimension of the tongue changes with sleep apnea is interesting. “However, when we screen patients with sleep apnea, we do check the upper airways.
