By reducing obesity, the severity of sleep apnea can be reduced. And tongue fat is one of the factors,” he said.

Dr Padegal said there are surgical options available to reduce tongue size, but that’s possible in case of less than 5% of patients. “Surgery to reduce muscle in tongue fat is considered for some patients, who have enlarged tongue and in some where the child has Down’s Syndrome with a fat tongue. Upper airway endoscopy helps in assessing what collapses inside the throat region,” he said.

Title: Bengaluru rooftops can generate 2500MW solar power: Survey
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Rooftops of 1.4 lakh buildings have the potential to generate 2,500MW of installed solar capacity, according to a Bescom survey using aerial light detection and ranging technology.

The survey was carried out across 1,176 sqkm in the city. Only 205MW capacity of SRTPV (solar rooftop photovoltaic) has been installed till July 2019 in the state, while Karnataka’s solar policy of 2014-21 set an ambitious target of 2,400MW for grid-connected solar rooftop projects.

Bescom will soon allow third-party investors to rent rooftops of domestic consumers and set up SRTPV systems under various business models.

On December 9, the Karnataka Electricity Regulatory Commission issued an order, detailing four business models to be followed for third-party investment in setting up solar plants at consumers’ homes. A developer/investor can now install, own and operate solar plants on a domestic consumer’s rooftop and sell energy at retail supply tariffs fixed by KERC.

Bescom has proposed a capital expenditure of Rs 1,275 crore for installation of hybrid solar rooftop plants with storage, with a capacity of 1060MW.

“We are identifying a consultant who will prepare a robust request for proposal document for the project,” said Bescom MD MB Rajesh Gowda.

Title: Bengaluru: Finance manager killed in accident
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A 33-year-old finance manager with a private firm was killed instantly after an unknown vehicle knocked down his scooter near NTTF college, Hosur Road, Electronics City Saturday midnight.

Electronics City police said Vishwanath R, a resident of Ananta Nagar and from Dharmapuri district in Tamil Nadu, was on his way to a car service station when the accident happened around 12.15am.

Vishwanath’s wife Rekha told police her husband had given his car for service on Saturday. “We were planning to go out on Sunday. So, my husband picked up a car from the service centre. But while bringing the vehicle home, he found that it had some problem. He complained to the service centre, which rushed their staff to the spot and towed the vehicle away for repair. My husband took his scooter to return to the service station when the accident occured,” police quoted Rekha as saying.

Preliminary probe revealed an unidentified vehicle hit Vishwanath’s scooter from behind, throwing him to the ground. The vehicle ran over his head.

Vishwanath is survived by his wife and a five-year-old son.

Police are verifying CCTV footage from the vicinity to identify the killer vehicle and nab the driver.

Title: Karnataka: Flyover to be named after Sangolli Rayanna
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

File photo of BS Yediyurappa

BENGALURU: The flyover at Anand Rao Circle , near Majestic, will be named after Krantiveera Sangolli Rayanna , the 19th-century military chief who fought against the British. The flyover connects west Bengaluru with the central business district.

Chief minister BS Yediyurappa made the announcement on the occasion of Rayanna’s 189th death anniversary on Sunday. Leader of the opposition Siddaramaiah demanded the CM release funds allotted for the development of Rayanna’s birthplace, Sangolli, and Nandagad where he died (both in Belagavi district).

Title: Republic Day 2020: Many firsts on 71st
Content:
As many as 22 tableaux took part in the parade.

NEW DELHI: India’s cultural diversity and military prowess were on full display during the 71st Republic Day celebrations on Sunday: a blanket of thick fog that engulfed the city in the morning and tight security restrictions could not deter the enthusiastic crowd from gathering at Rajpath.Like every year, the armed forces took centre stage, parading an array of weapons and the state-of-the-art technology at their disposal. As many as 22 tableaux — 16 from states and union territories and the rest from various ministries and departments — took part in the parade. The day saw many firsts: Brazil president Jair Messias Bolsonaro, the chief guest, was received by Prime Minister Modi, sporting a free-flowing orange turban, at the ceremony itself. Bolsonaro, the third Brazilian head of state to grace a Republic Day parade, was accompanied by his Indian counterpart, Ram Nath Kovind. This was followed by the customary 21-gun salute and hoisting of the tricolour.Earlier, in another break from tradition, PM Modi — accompanied by newly-appointed chief of defence staff General Bipin Rawat and the three service chiefs, General M M Naravane, Admiral Karambir Singh and Air Chief Marshal R K S Bhadauria, paid tributes to the country’s fallen soldiers at National War Memorial, instead of Amar Jawan Jyoti, ahead of the parade.Indigenously-developed battle tank T-90 Bhishma tank, infantry combat vehicle Ballway Machine Pikate, self-propelled K-9 Vajra gun and the Akash weapon system were the main attractions in the mechanised columns. Indigenous aircraft carrier INS Vikrant, which is under development at Kochi Shipyard, and the newly-inducted Chinook heavy lift and Apache choppers were the other major attractions.Captain Tania Sher Gill, an officer serving with Army’s Corps of Signals, led an all-male marching contingent during the 90-minute parade, drawing admiration from the audience. Sher Gill had recently made history by becoming the first woman parade adjutant to lead an all-men contingent during the Army Day function. Major Sheena Nayyar, the first Army officer in her family, led a contingent of the transportable satellite terminal. The satellite system provides fail-safe secure communication to the forces on the move. Women personnel were also part of the navy and air force marching contingents. At the end of the parade, an all-women team of CRPF showcased their daredevil skills on motorcycles.For the first time, a DRDO missile used during ‘Mission Shakti’ anti-satellite weapon test, which put India in the elite counter-space capability club, was shown during the parade.A 155mm “make-in-India” Dhanush gun, developed by Ordnance Factory Board, was also displayed for the first time during the parade. Initial clearance has been given for bulk production of the 155mm indigenous gun. A model of fourth-generation multirole fighter jet Rafale, which France will be delivering to India in phases as per the Rs 59,000-crore deal for 36 aircraft, was part of the parade. A “Saravatra Bridge” system, a five-metre short span bridge system and an air defence tactical control radar made their debut at the parade.In all, there were 16 marching contingents, six from Army and the rest from Navy, Air Force, Central Armed Police Forces, Delhi Police, National Cadet Corps and National Service Scheme. Apart from this, the 61st Cavalry in the uniform of the erstwhile Gwalior Lancers, the only active horse cavalry regiment in the world that was raised in 1953, took part.The flypast by IAF aircraft was unique this time as US-manufactured heavy-lift Chinook helicopters and deadliest attack helicopters Apaches, which were used in Iraq and Afghanistan war, made their debut. Both the imported helicopters, recently inducted into the IAF, flew in different formations over Rajpath.They were followed by Dornier aircraft, C-130J Super Hercules aircraft, an Airborne Early Warning and Control System aircraft and the “Globe” formation comprising three C-17 Globemasters, which left the viewers spellbound. Five Jaguar deep penetration strike aircraft and five upgraded MiG-29 air superiority fighters in “Arrowhead” formation displayed their aerial manoeuvres. At the end, a fleet of Sukhoi-30 MKI jets split the sky with a breathtaking “Vertical Charlie” aerobatic manoeuvre.

Title: Telangana to focus on literacy rate: Governor Tamilisai Soundararajan
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Telangana governor Tamilisai Soundararajan

HYDERABAD: Telangana governor Tamilisai Soundararajan said during her Republic Day speech that the state would soon announce an action plan for ‘each-one-teach-one’ programme to improve the literacy rate .

She added that the government had completed revenue reforms such as comprehensive revenue records purification to end land related litigations and disputes.

She also said that the government has implemented Palle Pragati (village progress) programme in two phases to improve villages with people’s participation. Now, the government is planning to take up Pattana Pragati (town progress).

“Since municipal elections are over, newly elected people’s representatives should take up the responsibility to change their towns and cities for better,” the governor said.

Title: Madras high court acquits man jailed for assaulting cop
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Madras high court

MADURAI: Madras high court has set aside the conviction and sentence imposed on a man who assaulted a police constable in Madurai in 1997, saying the trial court had not examined important witnesses.

The prosecution case is that constable Rathinamani of Teppakulam police received a phone call informing him that a person was being assaulted by seven others at Kuruvikaran Salai on March 28, 1997. When Rathinamani and an SI were searching for the accused in the southern and northern banks of Vaigai river, one of the accused, appellant Sikkandar, assaulted him using a sickle in which he sustained injuries.

Following the incident, the police registered a case against Sikkandar and he was arrested. The fast track court in Madurai convicted and sentenced him to undergo three years imprisonment under section 332 (voluntarily causes hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty as such public servant) of IPC on June 30, 2009. Sikkandar moved HC Madurai bench the same year challenging the order.

On perusal of the submissions, Justice B Pugalendhi observed that the police constable was assaulted by a rowdy element and the complainant is the same police constable. “Even though the investigation was conducted in such a shabby manner, the trial was concluded even without examining the relevant witnesses for arrest and recovery as well as the doctor who provided treatment to the constable,” he said.

Though an SI accompanied the constable at the time of occurrence, the person was also not examined. Hence the judge noted that it was not safe to sustain the conviction and sentence and acquitted the appellant of the charges framed against him.

Title: Shaheen Bagh suppressing the majority voice: Prasad
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

New Delhi: The Shaheen Bagh protest is emerging as a “textbook case of a few hundred people trying to suppress the silent majority”, Union minister of law Ravi Shankar Prasad alleged on Monday.

Prasad claimed that those trying to fragment India were getting shelter at the protest under the Tricolour. “It is offering a platform to ‘tukde tukde gang’ elements under the garb of opposition to Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). This protest is not just against CAA, it is against (PM Narendra) Modi,” he said at a press conference. “Innocent children are being tricked into threatening violence against the PM,” the BJP minister alleged.

“We want this issue to be raised prominently during the Delhi polls as to what kind of India and Delhi we want,” he emphasised. “Should Delhi have a place for those who raise ‘tukde tukde’ slogans or want to cut off Assam,” he said, referring to anti-CAA activist Sharjeel Imam who has been slapped with sedition charges for his alleged speeches.

Shaheen Bagh is not just a locality, but has become an “idea”, said Prasad. But CAA doesn’t deprive anyone of citizenship and each Muslim citizen will continue to live with full respect, he claimed.

“Lakhs of people are distressed because they cannot go to office, shops are shut and children can’t go to school due to the road blockade by protesters,” Prasad said.

Title: Army stocking up munitions for 40-day war
Content:
Army is slowly stocking up ammunition for 40-day war.

NEW DELHI: The 13-lakh strong Army is now slowly but steadily building its ammunition stocks ranging from rockets and missiles to high-caliber tank and artillery shells to ensure it can comfortably fight a full-blown war for over 10 days, with the eventual aim to have adequate stockpiles in place to last 40 days.Defence ministry sources say all the different types of ammunition for the Army will be built up to “10(I) levels”, which mean adequate stocks to undertake 10 days of “intensive” full-spectrum fighting, by 2022-2023, as per the latest assessment.This, of course, does not mean the Army is not operationally ready for war as of now. “It is, especially on the western front. But ammunition reserves have to be built keeping both Pakistan and China in mind,” said a source.The “earlier huge deficiencies” in several types of “critical” ammunition have already been “substantially plugged”, with more supplies in the pipeline under the 24 contracts (19 with foreign arms companies) worth Rs 12,890 crore inked for the Army.“The next target will be to gradually achieve 40(I) levels after some major rationalisation because not all types of ammunition are needed in such large numbers. Holding large reserves is neither economically nor logistically feasible,” said the source.The MoD is also in the process of contracting the domestic private sector to manufacture with foreign collaboration eight different types of tank, artillery and infantry ammunition worth around Rs 1,700 crore per year for a decade from 2022-2023 onwards.Over the last several years, at least since 2012, TOI has repeatedly reported the Army was fast running out of ammunition, with tanks and air defence units, artillery batteries and infantry soldiers all facing the crunch under the hugely depleted war wastage reserves (WWR). Successive parliamentary and CAG reports have also underscored the critical operational deficiency.But it took the Uri terror attack in September 2016 for the government to swing into action and delegate financial powers to the Army, Navy and IAF for “emergency and critical 10(I) contracts” after finding that the armed forces simply did not have enough ammunition stocks for a prolonged full-fledged war.Since then, contracts worth over Rs 24,000 crore for ammunition, spares, engines and other reserves have been inked for the three Services. The Army, for instance, is getting Smerch rockets, Konkurs anti-tank guided missiles, 125mm APFSDS (armour-piercing fin-stabilized discarding sabot) ammunition for its T-90S and T-72 tanks and other ammunition under the 19 contracts inked mainly with Russian and some other foreign companies.The defence ministry is also working to improve the functioning and quality control of the 41 factories under the state-owned Ordnance Factory Board (OFB), which supplies around 90 of the total 163 types of ammunition used by the Army.This came after the Army sounded the alarm about the unacceptably high number of accidents taking place due to the defective quality of ammunition being supplied for tanks, artillery, air defence and other guns by the OFB as well as the huge slippages in supply, as was reported by TOI in May last year.Just last month, the CAG had again slammed the OFB for compromising operational military readiness by failing to meet “a significant quantity” of the Army’s requirements as well as supplying defective fuses leading to multiple accidents.The Army, on its part, wants accountability to be fixed on those responsible for faulty quality checks and defective ammunition, which are leading to frequent accidents during firings of 105mm Indian field guns, 105mm light field guns, 130mm MA1 medium guns, 40mm L-70 air defence guns as well as the main guns of the T-72, T-90 and Arjun main-battle tanks.

Title: Republic Day 2020: Delhi's India Gate choked, five metro stations shut for over two hours
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Around 5pm, cops refused fresh entry to India Gate to allow people to move out peacefully

NEW DELHI: Republic Day celebrations stalled the capital on Sunday evening. According to an estimate, around 50,000 people gathered around India Gate , Delhi zoo and Hanuman temple at Kashmere Gate. As a preventive measure to stop more people from gathering at these locations, five Delhi Metro stations were shut for around two hours.

The footfall was several times more than what police had anticipated. The crowd started swelling by 3pm, with people flocking to the zoo or India Gate, which chocked traffic on Mathura Road. Policemen had to intermittently stop vehicle flow to allow pedestrians to cross the road.

There was a huge crowd at Connaught Place too, which lead to major traffic disruptions. “Five metro stations, including Khan Market, Pragati Maidan, Mandi House, Udyog Bhawan and Central Secretariat, were shut around 5pm after a large number of people started gathering at India Gate and to visit National War Memorial. Interchange facility was, however, available at Mandi House and Central Secretariat,” a senior police officer said.

It was disappointing for people who had come to India Gate as police refused fresh entry, thereby allowing people to move out peacefully. “The place will become chaotic if we allow more people to move in. We are trying to ensure no untoward incident takes place as the number of visitors is a lot more than usual,” a security officer posted at the war memorial said.

Traffic movement in the evening was affected as autorickshaws refused to travel near central Delhi. At Rajpath, on one side were people who had gathered to click selfies with the tricoloured India Gate, on the other side were enthusiastic people who wanted to see Rashtrapati Bhavan, North and South Block lit up.

Many visitors, who were denied entry to India Gate, could be seen arguing with police officers. The cops told them to enter from a different side where they were meted out the same treatment. “My friend had come to Delhi from Gwalior and we decided to take her to India Gate. But now they are saying we can’t go,” said Avika, a resident of Noida.

Title: Poll violence: Madras high court tells SP of Virudhunagar to file counter
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Madras high court has directed the Virudhunagar superintendent of police (SP) to file a counter in a plea moved by a DMK candidate seeking CBI or CB-CID inquiry in to a case, which was registered for violence during indirect election of Watrap panchayat union .

In his petition, S Kannan, a resident of Virudhunagar district , stated that he was fielded as a candidate for the post of chairman of Watrap panchayat union in the district. When the indirect election was conducted on January 11, he had secured seven votes and the candidate belonging to the AIADMK secured six votes.

He stated that since he secured more votes, the members of the ruling party created ruckus during the election. With the help of Srivilliputhur DSP Rajendran, the ruling party members entered the building where election was held and caused damages to the property.

They attempted to tear the ballot papers, but the returning officer took control of the ballot papers and kept them in his safe custody. Following the incident, the election was stopped, he stated.

Though the police officials knew the identity of those who were involved in the violence during the election, a case has been registered against unknown people. The DSP was primarily responsible for stopping the election. Action should be initiated against him, he stated..

Though he submitted a representation to the authorities concerned along with the video footage, no steps were taken in this regard.

Hence, the petitioner moved HC Madurai bench seeking CBI or CB-CID inquiry into the case, which was registered for violence reported during indirect election conducted for Watrap panchayat union.

When the case was heard on Friday, Justice A D Jagadish Chandira directed Virudhunagar SP to file a counter and adjourned the case to February 6 for further hearing.

Title: Delhi elections: Arvind Kejriwal on your smartphone, with govt’s achievements
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: Arvind Kejriwal on Monday unveiled an innovative micro-level campaign “Kejriwal Aap Ke Dwaar” for assembly elections under which the chief minister aims to “visit every household in the city and deliver a talk on the government’s achievements.” Kejriwal appealed to people to visit welcomekejriwal.in or give a missed call to 7690944444, following which he will appear on the screens of smartphones or computers.When one visits the website, the CM presses the doorbell of the house. With folded hands, he says, “Namaskar, I am Arvind Kejriwal. May I come in? Hope you aren’t busy.” A ‘Welcome’ sign pops up on the screen, which says click below to know more. Once a user clicks on it, Kejriwal drinks water and says: “Thank you for giving me the opportunity to come to your house and speak.”He subsequently asks the user to pick sectors like education, health, water, unauthorised colonies, electricity, women empowerment and infrastructure. If a person selects electricity, for example, Kejriwal takes a seat and starts explaining the work done in the sector for 2.45 minutes. He spends 7.2 minutes talking about the work done in health sector and 5.6 minutes on the water sector. He also briefly explains the future plans to the viewers watching the campaign from the comfort of their homes. A specially designed software fires the campaign.“Delhi is a city of two crore people and approximately 50 lakh families. I wanted to visit every household and meet all the family members personally through door-to-door campaigning and inform them of all the work done in the last five years. It is not possible to physically visit each of the 50 lakh households,” Kejriwal said, adding that the campaign was designed to meet this objective.“You can also share your feedback. We will try to include your suggestions and I will personally make sure to work on your complaints after the elections,” said Kejriwal.Under education sector, Kejriwal covers work in government schools, foreign training for teachers, coaching for competitive examinations, no hike in private school fees in the last five years, among others.In the health sector, the CM explains infrastructural boost at hospitals, construction of more than 450 mohalla clinics and polyclinics, etc. The government’s work in unauthorised colonies is also highlighted.The CM explains provision of 24-hour power supply, 200 units of free electricity and electricity at half rate for consumption up to 400 units. Around 32 lakh families have received zero electricity bills in December, he says.Kejriwal promises that proper planning and mapping have been done to provide 24-hour clean and safe tap water to all in the city within a year and cleaning of Yamuna river in the next five years.In the campaign video, Kejriwal also promises infrastructure boost and women’s safety measures, including installation of 1.4 lakh more CCTV cameras and deployment of 13,000 marshals in DTC buses.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Server issues cripple trial of online aptitude test for classes IX, X students
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The online aptitude test held for students of Class IX and Class X in all government schools across Tamil Nadu , including in Madurai , was marred by poor network server connectivity and technical issues on Friday.

“This was only an experiment. When lakhs of students are writing an exam, there is bound to be network server errors. This was just a trial so that in future we know what needs to be done,” said a district education department official.

The aptitude test, which tested the general knowledge of students, was held to get students comfortable with giving exams online so as to perform well in competitive entrance tests like Joint Entrance Examination (JEE) and National Eligibility cum Entrance Test-Under Graduate (Neet) in the future.

“We made whatever arrangements possible to ensure that the online test was conducted without disruption because we wanted to motivate students. We held the test in batches because we had only a few computers. The students were given a login ID by which they had to sign in and complete the exam. It was a new experience for them,” said the principal of a government high school.

Both students and teachers hope that online tests will be conducted more frequently so that they too can match private schools in quality.

Title: Delhi: Eye on ground and in skies to keep trouble at bay
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Republic Day parade in Delhi's Rajpath

NEW DELHI: The capital was on Sunday put under a multi-layered, ground-to-air security cover with thousands of armed personnel keeping a tight vigil. Visitors to Republic Day parade were not only put through an extra round of frisking but were also not allowed to carry any metallic object, including coins. The entry to the venue was delayed as the visitors were told to leave behind anything that could possibly be thrown at the VVIPs.

The security was reviewed after intelligence inputs were received that protesters, carrying anti-CAA messages, could attempt to enter the enclosures. Apart from conducting a deep search of “suspicious” visitors, the cops deployed for coordination duty didn’t allow people to stand up or walk towards the grille around Rajpath.

For the first time, Delhi Police launched its mobile police control room van that was stationed at Rajpath to ensure seamless communication with other agencies. Facial-recognition cameras were installed at all light poles along Rajpath to keep an eye on the visitors. Apart from an anti-drone alert, flying of paragliders, hot-air balloons and remotely piloted aircraft was prohibited.

A team of sharpshooters from National Security Guard, along with spotters, was positioned on all highrises around Rajpath. An additional 48 companies of paramilitary forces assisted the nearly 22,000-strong Delhi Police force. Two anti-terror and crime control vans — Parakram and Prakhar — was deployed along the parade route.

Apart from securing the main venue, adequate security and traffic arrangements for the “At Home” at Rashtrapati Bhavan were made.

Security was tightened around popular markets, malls and other crowded places, too. The borders were secured and close coordination maintained with police of neighbouring states. “Surprise checks were carried out by placing barricades at various places. India Gate and other places of tourist interests were kept secure in view of the visitors’ rush,” said Eish Singh, DCP (New Delhi).

Rajpath remained inaccessible to general traffic till 12 noon, till when the entry and exit gates of Central Secretariat, Udyog Bhawan, Patel Chowk and Lok Kalyan Marg metro stations were also closed, beginning from 8.45am. All arterial roads in Lutyens’ Delhi were access-controlled through colour stickers that were provided for vehicles and visitors. Over 2,000 traffic cops were deployed to keep vehicle flow under check.

Title: Madras high court upholds pharmacist’s sacking
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Madras high court has upheld the termination of service of a woman who was working as pharmacist in an ESI dispensary, saying the charges against her for submitting forged documents to avail of a loan have been proved beyond doubt.

Petitioner C Helen Rani was appointed as pharmacist at the ESI dispensary in 1978. She borrowed a sum of Rs 1 lakh from the Madurai District Medical Department Employees ’ Cooperative Thrift Society, Tirumangalam, in 2001. Since the petitioner could not repay the loan, the society attached her salary. When the loan was still outstanding, the petitioner applied for another loan in 2003 by submitting a no-dues certificate. However, the cooperative society found that forged documents were submitted and hence a police complaint was lodged against her. An inquiry found that Helen Rani had submitted a forged no-dues certificate to the society and consequently she was terminated from service.

The petitioner moved HC Madurai bench in 2013 seeking to quash the termination order and reinstate her. On perusal of submissions made by either side, Justice S S Sundar observed that the petitioner has fraudulently obtained a loan which was unbecoming of a government servant. She suppressed the existing loan through the forged certificate and produced a forged salary certificate by forging the signature of the officer of her establishment. “When the petitioner produced forged documents for the purpose of getting a sum of Rs 1lakh, she may not hesitate to accept bribe for doing anything against the interest of the department for the sake of her own benefit,” observed the judge. Rejecting the contention of the petitioner that there cannot be a parallel proceeding departmentally when the case was pending before the criminal court, the judge observed that she was found guilty of the charges by the criminal court though she was discharged on probation upon payment of the entire loan amount to the cooperative society.

Title: Rescued Indian dogs find forever homes thousands of miles away
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Indian dogs are being adopted by many families in the US, Europe and Canada, and are considered among the best... Read More

HYDERABAD: Kittu, a two-year-old stray dog that was rescued from the streets of Hyderabad is now enjoying the white sand beaches of Jacksonville, the largest city in northeastern Florida.

Found unconscious in the middle of the road, Kittu was rescued and adopted by Ujwala Chintala, a US national who was on a trip to India in December 2019.

Speaking to TOI, Chintala said, "I personally rescued Kittu while I was driving in Mansoorabad, Hyderabad. We found Kittu with a shattered leg and heavy mastitis. She was a mother dog when we found her, but her puppies were not to be found. They may not have survived".

"After getting the treatment done, I decided to adopt Kittu and take him to Florida. Stray Dog Support Inc. generously helped to bring her to the US, while Poochies Pet Rescue, Inc. took a bold decision to take Kittu into their rescue. All for the welfare of this much-needed dog," said Chintala.

Like Kittu, several stray dogs in India, rescued by a non-governmental organisation (NGO) in Hyderabad and elsewhere in the country are now finding homes in the US, Europe and Canada. While a majority of Indians still fancy having pedigree breeds such as Labradors, Huskies, German Shepherds and St Bernards as pets, the Indian native dogs or the Indian Pariahs that are forced to survive in squalid conditions on our streets are being considered one of the best dog breeds abroad. In another instance, Monkey (now named Picabo), a paralysed pup who survived all kinds of harsh conditions on the streets a few months ago and Paavan whose face was consumed by a tumour are both winning hearts of their new families in Washington DC, US.

Posting a video of Picabo on a Facebook group (Stray Dog Support Inc.) dedicated to stray dogs, the NGO that arranged Picabo’s adoption and transfer to the US wrote, “Monkey (Picabo) our recent arrival from India is enjoying her first Christmas toy! This little girl is winning the hearts of her new adoptive family. We are so happy for this little paralyzed pup who survived the harsh streets.” While two other street survivors Posto and Chochori also have new homes in the US, Xena whose mother and three siblings died due to severe mange soon after the delivery has been adopted by a Canadian resident and is now living at Port Alberni, a city in Vancouver Island, Canada.

“Stray Dog Support is dedicated to save and improve the lives of defenceless and vulnerable street dogs around the world including India. We work to provide financial support to these local rescuers who often go without food and basic needs in order to help these at-risk dogs. We also help facilitate the transport of these street pups internationally,” said Helen Summerfield Brown of Stray Dog Support Inc.

In 2019, an NGO Peedu’s People sent 43 dogs to their forever homes in Canada, USA and UK . Out of 43 dogs this year, 21 were special needs (paralyzed, tripods, blind, deaf etc) and 39 were orphans. In four years, the NGO got a total of 117 Indian dogs adopted abroad. NGO volunteers who organize adoption and transfer of stray dogs to other countries said that they do all necessary background checks and review applications of the possible adopter when they approach them.

“The process of adoption is simple, and all the expenses are for transport and permissions are made by the adopters themselves,” informed Singh. The cost of transporting a dog from India to the US, Europe and Canada can be anywhere between Rs 1 lakh to Rs 2 lakh depending on the country.

“It usually costs less if the pet travels with the adopter or a foster who can handover the pet to the permanent owners after they reach the country in which it is getting adopted,” said Singh. “At the end of the day these desi dogs show the world how fantastic, smart, intelligent and loving they are. They are changing the perception of the Indian pariah dog, slowly but surely. More importantly they show us Indians that our dogs have value, that they should adopt and save a life than spend on expensive breeds,” said Inder Sandhu of Peedu’s People.

Title: Jubilation marks gram sabha meet with newly elected
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Madurai: Enthusiasm was high among the people as the gram sabhas met under the leadership of newly elected panchayat presidents and vice-presidents in the villages in the districts on Sunday. On their part, the elected representatives used the opportunity to thank the people for electing them and promised to enhance basic amenities in their villages.

In Madurai, district collector Dr T G Vinay participated in the meeting held at A Kokkulam village in Thirumangalam panchayat union. He said that gram sabhas provided an opportunity for the people to get benefits from the government. Accounts of the panchayat works can be viewed and people can participate in the audit to ensure that the funds are utilised to the fullest. Education was the basis for all development and parents should ensure that their children went to school and had access to education, he said. Anganwadis were providing quality meals to the children and the department of school education was providing free textbooks and computers to the students to encourage them.

Awareness was being created among the public to make them refrain from using banned single use plastics. In Tuticorin, the district collector participated in the meeting held at Nattathi village in Srivaikuntam panchayat union, which was presided over by newly elected president S Thakala. The collector distributed tricycles for implementing solid waste management in the panchayat.

Title: K Chandrasekhar Rao: Telangana CM Chandrasekhar Rao to pay surprise visits to villages
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Telangana CM K Chandrashekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: Expressing dissatisfaction over cleanliness efforts being taken up under ‘Palle Pragathi’ programme, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao said it has become a photo shoot event for some ministers, collectors and public representatives.

The CM said he would carry out surprise checks to review the ground situation. “Some ministers, collectors and public representatives are posing for photos for the media for publicity sake and claiming that they are cleaning the villages as part of Palle Pragathi programme . This is not correct. It is not their duty to sweep the villages, they only have to ensure that the work assigned is done properly,” KCR said during a review meeting on Palle Pragathi on Sunday.

“The required staff has been recruited in gram panchayats and their salaries have been increased. It is the responsibility of officials and public representatives to find out how the cleanliness works in the villages are going on? I will make surprise visits to the villages to review the ground situation,” the CM added.

He said the sanitation works should be done on a daily basis and village nurseries have been made compulsory for improving greenery in villages. With inspiration drawn from Palle Pragathi, Pattana (town progress) programme would also be launched shortly.

The CM also asked officials to take steps to ensure that Hyderabad and other cities don’t not turn into pollution ridden cities. “There is about 1.60 lakh hectares of forest land available inside and outside of Hyderabad. Grow trees in large numbers on these lands and transform them into dense forest. Ten per cent of the GHMC and HMDA budget funds should be utilised for increasing the green cover,” the chief minister said.

He asked the officials to prepare Haritha Haram plans for other cities and towns too by creating one nursery per ward. All the towns and cities in Telangana should be resplendent with greenery, he said.

Title: Faridabad: Engineer who lost son in accident fills potholes
Content:
Manoj Wadhwa spent time going through tutorials on how to fill potholes .

FARIDABAD: Frustrated with the state machinery’s failure to fix potholes on Faridabad roads, Manoj Wadhwa, a telecom engineer, and a few friends took to filling up some potholes themselves on Sunday. Wadhwa knows better than others what irreparable loss and pain a crater on the road can cause since he lost his three-year-old son in a pothole-related road accident on the Delhi-Agra highway six years ago.Wadhwa spent time going through tutorials on how to fill potholes from two groups — Pothole Warriors in Mumbai and Pothole Raja in Bengaluru — before he reached the identified site with three bags of mixed bitumen and other necessary items. The team brushed the identified site to take out the dust and then poured the cold-mix to fill the potholes.Pothole Warriors and Pothole Raja have been carrying out several campaigns to fill potholes to highlight the inefficiency of municipal bodies and other road owning agencies.“We chose Sunday (Republic Day) to fill potholes with the hope that this will wake up government agencies. If a few of us can fill potholes, why can’t government agencies and contractors do this small thing despite having all resources at their disposal,” Wadhwa said.He said had there not been a pothole on the Delhi-Agra highway on February 10, 2014, he would not have lost his son Pavitra. “He would have been nine years now. Negligence of agencies ruined our happiness forever. I don’t want anyone else to go through this pain of losing a family member. Now, it’s mission of life and I don’t get disheartened even if I don’t get very encouraging support from others,” Wadhwa said.His fight against potholes started soon after he lost Pavitra and he has been fighting a long legal battle against National Highways Authority of India and a private construction firm to fix responsibility for the pothole that claimed his son.The accident took place when Wadhwa and his wife were returning from a marriage party. “Pavitra was sitting between me and my wife. I spotted a pool of water on the highway and applied brakes. As I lost balance, Pavitra fell on a sharp stone, which hit his chest. A vehicle coming from behind ran over my wife’s legs. Pavitra was declared brought dead when we reached hospital,” he said.

Title: Children make their presence felt
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Madurai: As the first gram sabha meeting of the year was held in all the 420 village panchayats in Madurai district on Sunday, active participation of children was seen at several villages.

A girl from Meenakshipuram panchayat in Madurai east panchayat union attracted attention when she requested bus facility to the village on behalf of her friends. Sahana, the fifth standard student, stood up and urged the president to provide a TNSTC bus service from their village to the government higher secondary school at Mayandipatti, which was attended by many boys and girls from her village. There was big applause from the crowd as she made the request. About 60 students from Meenakshipuram attend the government higher secondary school at Mayandipatti. Many of them do not have personal transport and have to walk for 7 kilometres, taking shortcuts through private land, which is unsafe. “They also have to bypass a Tasmac shop on the way, and parents feel anxious until they return home,” said Parvathy, a villager, adding that the little girl’s request had been unexpected, but it was something that their village needed very much. Panchayat president S Pandeeswari, who presided over the gram sabha in Meenakshipuram village, promised to take steps. A large number of women from hamlets of Poosaripatti, Perumalpatti and Arapallam participated in the meet.

Selvi, a villager, said as their panchayat president is a woman, they felt confident of reaching out to her and seeking facilities for their village.tnn

Title: Madurai: Children make their presence felt
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

MADURAI: As the first gram sabha meeting of the year was held in all the 420 village panchayats in Madurai district on Sunday, active participation of children was seen at several villages.

A girl from Meenakshipuram panchayat in Madurai east panchayat union attracted attention when she requested bus facility to the village on behalf of her friends. Sahana, the fifth standard student, stood up and urged the president to provide a TNSTC bus service from their village to the government higher secondary school at Mayandipatti , which was attended by many boys and girls from her village.

There was big applause from the crowd as she made the request. About 60 students from Meenakshipuram attend the government higher secondary school at Mayandipatti. Many of them do not have personal transport and have to walk for 7 kilometres, taking shortcuts through private land, which is unsafe. “They also have to bypass a Tasmac shop on the way, and parents feel anxious until they return home,” said Parvathy, a villager, adding that the little girl’s request had been unexpected, but it was something that their village needed very much. Panchayat president S Pandeeswari, who presided over the gram sabha in Meenakshipuram village, promised to take steps. A large number of women from hamlets of Poosaripatti, Perumalpatti and Arapallam participated in the meet.

Selvi, a villager, said as their panchayat president is a woman, they felt confident of reaching out to her and seeking facilities for their village.

Title: Colourful events mark R-Day in southern dists
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Madurai: Pomp and pageantry marked Republic Day celebrations in the southern districts, with district collectors distributing welfare measures and honouring freedom fighters.

In Madurai, district collector Dr T G Vinay hoisted the tricolour at the armed reserve ground and inspected the guard of honour by the police. Government officials and police personnel were honoured with medals by the collector for their outstanding service. Welfare measures including agriculture loans and disability pension among others to the tune of Rs 56.64 lakh were distributed to 177 beneficiaries. City commissioner of police S Davidson Devasirvatham and SP N Manivannan among others participated in the event.

As part of Republic Day celebrations by the corporation, commissioner S Visakan hoisted the national flag and distributed welfare measures. Private hospitals, companies and residential organisations also celebrated the event grandly.

In Virudhunagar district, school and college students performed colourful dances while district collector R Kannan distributed welfare measures worth Rs 48.19 lakh to beneficiaries. Sivaganga district J Jayakanthan inspected the guard of honour and distributed welfare measures.

The chief minister’s medal was awarded to 73 police personnel for their outstanding service by Theni district collector Pallavi M Baldev and 23 beneficiaries received benefits amounting to Rs 12.29 lakh. Welfare measures to the tune of Rs 1 crore were distributed by Ramanathapuram district collector K Veera Raghava Rao at the event held in the district.

A flock of doves were released as a mark of peace during the celebrations in Dindigul district where district collector M Vijayalakshmi hoisted the flag and distributed welfare measures. Tyagis were honoured for their service to the nation.

Each event was witnessed by a large number of public who pinned the tricolour on their dresses. Flags and sweets were also distributed at many places. Colourful events also marked the celebrations in Tirunelveli, Tuticorin and Kanyakumari.

Title: Madurai railway division earnings go up by 8.9%
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Madurai: Gross earnings of Madurai railway division in the first three quarters of 2019-20 stood at Rs 632.6 crore, which is 8.9% more than that of the earnings of the same period in the previous year. Divisional railway manager (DRM) V R Lenin said this while highlighting the achievements of the division from April to December 2019 at the 71st Republic Day celebrations organised by the division on Sunday.

The division also recorded an operating ratio of 94.19% against the earnings. Rs 91.13 crore was spent under various plan heads spread over passenger amenities and staff welfare, against the target of Rs 79.39 crore. Despite more traffic blocks and track works, the punctuality of express and passenger trains stood at 91% and 94.1% respectively. Rs 4.87 crore was collected as fine through intensive ticket checking and is 43.6% more than last year. Rs 5.23 crore was earned through sale of scrap against Rs 4.91 crore last year.

Railway Protection Force (RPF) rescued 199 abandoned children found in trains and railway stations and handed over to their respective parents and NGOs. Drives conducted by RPF in trains and on railway premises against littering activities resulted in apprehension of 7,789 defaulters, from them fine to the tune of Rs 18,72,500 was collected in the nine-month period.

The DRM said that the Madurai–Usilampatti stretch gauge conversion work as part of the Madurai–Bodinayakanur conversion has been completed till Usilampatti and will be opened for passenger traffic shortly. Vaigai Express with ICF coaches was converted to faster and safer LHB rake. As on date eight pairs of trains were converted into LHB rakes. Apart from regular trains, the division has run 299 special trains. As many as 38 stations were provided with high speed free Wi-Fi facility during the nine months, taking the total number of stations with the facility in the division to 95. A total of 14 manned level crossings have been eliminated. Two road over bridges and nine limited use subways have been built.

Title: People throng renovated HDMC swimming pool to beat the heat
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

The renovated swimming pool in Hubballi

HUBBALLI: With mercury levels rising, swimming pools in the city are witnessing a heavy rush.

The newly renovated Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation ( HDMC ) swimming pool developed under smart city project is abuzz with activities the entire day.

With men and women of all ages thronging the pool in large numbers, the daily collection has touched Rs 5,000 and the collection triples on weekends.

“We are glad the pool is finally renovated. Earlier, the authorities would close the pool frequently for maintenance works. Now, the swimming pool is well equipped and we are hopeful that authorities will maintain it properly and help citizens, particularly youths to make a mark in competitions by making use of this facility,” a visitor said.

“We have kept Rs 50 as the entry fee for everyone irrespective of age for now. Once the pool is handed over to HDMC, we will take a call on the entry fee and other matters,” said Shakeel Ahmed, managing director, Hubballi-Dharwad Smart City Limited.

The authorities will soon issue tender for operations and management of the pool and upon completion of the process, it will be handed over to HDMC, said sources.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Marigolds are in full bloom, but farmers not getting expected returns this season
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

This year farmers are getting only Rs 20 for a kilogram of maligold, against last year’s Rs 50/kg, due to a gl... Read More

MADURAI: Marigolds have bloomed in plentiful at Chinnalapatti in Dindigul district , but their falling prices have disappointed farmers. Farmers have cultivated yellow and orange marigolds at Oothupatti, Kamalapuram, Perumalkovilpatti, Jathikoundapatti, Theppampatti, Nadupatti, Kathirpatti and Sempatti. It has also bloomed at Pachamalaiyankottai and Seevalsaragu in the district.

S Rajadurai, a farmer, said they had started the cultivation three months ago. The plants have developed well due to recent rains, and now they are in full bloom. Saplings were purchased at Siruvani in Coimbatore and Hosur. A single hybrid sapling costs about 1.80 and 15,000 saplings can be planted in one acre.

Farmers said that the flower had good demand this season as they are widely used in temples for decorations and in rituals. As this is also the wedding season, the flowers are in high demand. That’s why many farmers opted for marigolds, which has led to a glut in the market bringing down the prices, farmers said.

The red soil in Dindigul region adds colour to marigolds grown in this area, say farmers. It is cultivated twice a year by the farmers, once in June and then in October. “When conditions are conducive, like they are now, we get a good harvest of about 400 to 500 kilograms of flowers once a week from an acre,’’ said Saravanakumar, a farmer. Most of the flowers produced in this region are taken to the Dindigul and Nilakottai flower markets by the farmers. Last year farmers sold marigolds at 50 a kilogram, but this year they are getting only 20 a kilogram, leading to a loss.

“We have to pick these flowers as early as 3am and take them to the market by 7am when they are fresh. But this year’s price is very disappointing,’’ said Saravanakumar.

Title: GHMC to construct eight new FOBs, two skywalks in Secunderabad zone
Content:
The GHMC recently received administrative sanctions for construction of the FOBs, which have been pending for ... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: Come February, the Secunderabad zone is all set to welcome eight new foot-over bridges ( FOBs ) and two skywalks consrtucted by the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ( GHMC ) and the Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority ( HMDA ).The GHMC recently received administrative sanctions for construction of the FOBs, which have been pending for the past two years.“A cost of Rs 16.91 crore has been sanctioned for eight new FOBs and Rs 13.30 crores has been sanctioned for two skywards in the Secunderabad. The work shall commence from February first week,” said Srinivas Reddy, zonal commissioner of Secunderabad, GHMC.According to officials, the eight new FOBs will come up at would come up at Neredmet busy stop, St Ann’s College of Education, St Ann’s Junior College for Girls in Tarnaka, Rail Nilayam, Ramakrishna Math at Lower Tank Bund, Ashok Nagar crossroads, between Himayat Nagar cross roads and Narayanguda flyover and Gandhi Medical College and Hospital in Musheerabad.The skywalks will come up at RTC crossroads and Chilkalguda.Many students near St Ann’s College of Education in Secunderabad are forced to cross the roads amidst heavy traffic due to lack of an FOB. “Every day a traffic cop is seen helping students cross the road by halting traffic. When a cop is unavailable, it is very difficult for students and parents to cross the road,” said Manjulatha K, a resident of West Marredpally.Apart from this, GHMC has also planned to conduct junction improvement works across Secunderabad zone. As part of junction improvement work, the GHMC has also plans of constructing bus shelters. The work is expected to be completed within a period of six months by June.

Title: Karnataka: Four including seer killed in road accident
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

The mangled car being removed from the accident spot on NH-4.

DHARWAD: The NH-4 bypass between Narendra Cross and Gabbur Cross proved to be a death trap yet again on Sunday as four person died and three others sustained injuries after two cars collided head on.

The deceased are pontiff of Shivanand Math in Kundgol, Basaveshwara Swami, 50, and Shankaragouda Patil, 60, of Noolvi in Kundgol taluk of Dharwad district who were travelling in a car from Kundgol to Dharwad and Mahadev Kadeshgol, 55, and Maruti Kuknur, 30, both residents of Kabbur village in Chikkodi taluk of Belagavi district, who were in a car that was on its way to Bengaluru.

Basavaraj Pujar, Siddappa Ingalli and Somalinga Desai, who were travelling with the pontiff sustained serious injuries and are undergoing treatment at the District Civil Hospital in Dharwad. Police said that the seer was going in the car to Dharwad to attend the wedding of a devotee.

The impact of the accident was such that both the cars were crushed and cranes were deployed to shift the cars and make way for vehicular movement. Following the grisly accident, traffic on the road was disrupted for more than 30 minutes.

This is the second accident on the same spot in a gap of one week. Three persons died on the spot on the Makara Sankranti festival.

The road needs to be widened into a six lane. As of now it is two-lane stretch of 30 kms. Legal tangle involving the state government and the Nandi Highways is said to have blocked the development works.

Dharwad Rural police have registered a case.

Ghastly accident: A crane removing the badly mangled car from the accident spot to clear the road for traffic near Yerikoppa on NH-4 bypass off Dharwad on Sunday

Title: Hundreds sit on indefinite dharna in Raichur to oppose CAA
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Raichur: The Anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) movement is gathering momentum in Raichur district too. The region which saw sporadic protests is now all set to sit for an indefinite dharana.

People under the banner of Citizens Forum for Constitutional Rights (CFCR) kick-started a day-and-night indefinite demonstration on Republic Day on Sunday. After hoisting the national flag, people began the agitation at the Tipu Garden in front of the deputy commissioner’s office.

Many organisations have come together to form this forum to launch the agitation. Raghavendra Kushtagi, one of the organisers, said, “The government’s clarifications on CAA are to fool the people and further the agenda of Hindutva by dividing nation on religious lines.”

Kushtagi said although government is urging the people not to view CAA in the prism of NRC, the government’ activities suggest clear link between these two. In Bengaluru and Madikeri verification of immigrants are being conducted. BBMP (Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike) has demolished houses of people. “People are not fools not to understand what is happening. In order to oppose this, indefinite protest is launched,” he said.

Khaja Aslam another protester said it has now become a duty to protect brotherhood and harmony among the people. The government is dividing people and planting communal hatred, he added.

R Manasayya, who is also spearheading the protest, said, “We are hoping that country’ apex court may rule in favour of people to protect the values of the Constitution. The protest will go on until CAA is taken back,” he said.

On day one, nearly 300 people gathered at the site and it is expected that everyday nearly 400-500 people will sit for dharna on rotation. In the night hours at least 50 people will sit at the place. Many cultural activities will be held at the place to spread communal harmony.

Title: Karnataka: Convict jumps from tree in prison premises, dies
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

DHARWAD: A 29-year-old convict ,who was lodged at Dhawrad Central jail , jumped from a tree in the prison premises and succumbed to injuries. The incident happened on Sunday.

Chetankumar of Holalkere in Chitradurga district , who was convicted and sentenced to 10-year imprisonment in a rape case, had been brought to Dharwad prison from Ballari a few days ago. He had moved the high court against his conviction and the matter was pending before the court.

When there was an order to shift him back to Ballari jail, Chetankumar had been making repeated appeals to the authorities to shift him to Shivamogga jail but in vain. On January 15, he had climbed a tree in the jail premises and threatened to jump from there if his pleas were not heeded. The jail staff had managed pursue and to get him back into the cell.

On Sunday, while the staff was busy celebrating the Republic Day, he reportedly climbed the tree again and jumped down. He suffered head injuries and succumbed on the way to hospital.

Police have registered a case of unnatural death and investigation is on.

Title: Autowallahs fined over ad, move HC
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A group of auto-rickshaw drivers have moved Delhi high court challenging their prosecution by traffic police officers for sporting a political advertisement — “I love Kejriwal” — logo on their vehicles.

The petitioners claimed the challans slapped on them on this ground violated their fundamental right to free speech and they could not be penalised for “expressing their opinion in a permitted manner”.

The first petition by Rajesh, likely to be taken up for hearing on Tuesday, told the court that he was an auto driver and barely managed to make a living.

“The the petitioner had got painted words “I love kejriwal” and “Sirf kejriwal” on the back of his vehicle in September-October 2019, of his free will and without any coercion, allurement, inducement, monetary incentive or force from anyone,” Rajesh’s petition argued, blaming the traffic cops for unilaterally booking him.

As per the petitioner, without any prior warning or missive from any government department, earlier this month his vehicle was stopped near Apollo hospital by traffic cops and he was illegally challaned for permit violations under various provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act, while also being slapped with a fine of Rs 10,000 on account of the symbols and markings on his auto.

The plea said that Rajesh was prosecuted for displaying an “advertisement of a political party” and violating the model code of conduct in force in the city due to the upcoming assembly elections.

A second petition seeking similar relief was filed by three other auto-rickshaw owners who were challaned by traffic cops “for painting a statement of adulation/admiration for a public figure on their vehicles”. Citing a 2018 high court order, the petitioners maintained that even if the symbols were seen as political advertisement, these were exempted from the Delhi Motor Vehicle Rules as per government’s statement in court then.

Title: Liquor consumption in Belagavi goes up by 7%
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

Title: HC seeks response of HRD, Jamia on VC’s appointment
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

New Delhi: Delhi high court on Monday sought the response of the Centre and Jamia Millia Islamia on a plea challenging the appointment of the current vice-chancellor Najma Akhtar.

Justice AK Chawla issued a notice to Union ministry of human resource development, Central Vigilance Commission, University Grants Commission, Jamia and Akhtar seeking their stand on the petition by a lawyer, who is also an alumnus.

The plea by M Ehtesham-ul-Haque alleged that Akhtar’s appointment was invalid on the ground that the search committee mandated to select prospective candidates for the post was constituted illegally. It was also claimed that she was denied CVC clearance initially, which was subsequently revoked after the HRD ministry’s intervention.

“It is submitted that the entire process culminating into the impugned appointment of Najma Akhtar is a colourable exercise of power and in flagrant violation and total non-compliance of the statutory provisions of the Jamia Millia Islamia Act, 1988,” the plea further alleged, urging HC to declare her appointment as VC “illegal, arbitrary, void ab initio and non est in law”.

In his plea, Haque also argued that laws governing establishment and running of Jamia were “sacrosanct” and couldn’t be interfered with by any authority. “JMI Act and statutes are binding on the university and all its functionaries,” the plea underlined, assailing a central minister’s move to recommend a panel of names for the appointment in 2018.

Referring to the search committee set up by the Centre that finally zeroed in on Akhtar, the petition claimed that minutes of the proceedings of the panel showed “neither was academic excellence nor exposure to the higher education system or adequate experience in academic and administrative governance was considered by the committee”. This was despite the fact that the panel was required to record its satisfaction that the three nominees were persons of highest level of competence, integrity morals and institutional commitment, the plea added.

Title: Hyderabad government schools submit application for post-paid meters, uninterrupted power
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Fearing that power supply may get be snapped if they fail to recharge on time, 682 government schools , who have been provided with prepaid electric meters, in the city have submitted a request for converting these meters into post-paid ones.

The district education officer (DEO), Hyderabad said a representation has been submitted to the director of the school education (DSE) office to ensure that meters were converted into post-paid ones.

“Right now, there won’t be any problem as the budget to recharge meters in all government schools in the district has been released. So, there won’t be any problem till March 2020. However, we want the meters to be post-paid so as to ensure that there won’t be any problems even in the future,” DEO, Hyderabad, B Venkata Narasamma said.

She said the budget to clear electric bills is usually released in June. “With the post-paid meters , even if the bills are not paid for a couple of months, there will no disruption of power supply. But, with prepaid meters, we won’t have that option,” she added.

The officials said they had already orally requested Telangana State Southern Power Distribution Company Limited (TSSPDCL) for conversion of meters, but the request would be looked into after the DSE sends a written representation.

Teachers working in government schools too said that it would be better if meters were converted into post-paid ones.

“If the power supply is suddenly disrupted, especially during the examinations, it will be a problem for students. If the connections are post-paid, such a situation will not arise,” Chava Ravi of the United Teachers’ Federation said.

The teachers also said that when the electricity charges were paid after the bill gets generated, the entire amount would be cleared. However, with prepaid meters, the schools might have to explain why bill exceeded the recharge amount, in case they have to top-up in the middle of the month.

During 2018-19, the discom had installed 10,500 meters in district collectorates, government schools, police stations and electric crematoria in HMDA jurisdiction. Government departments were picked by the discoms to put an end to the issues arising out of bill arrears. While the government offices’ power bill works out to Rs 120 crore to Rs 130 crore a month, the discom gets only Rs 50 crore to Rs 60 crore a month.

Title: Mangaluru: District minister backs police handling of bomb case
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

NCC cadets march in perfect synchroinsation at the Republic Day celebration in Mangaluru on Sunday.

MANGALURU: District minister Kota Srinivas Poojari said, “Dakshina Kannada is facing multiple challenges on the law and order front. Despite this, the district administration has been successful in upholding peace and communal amity.

Mangaluru city police competently handled the bomb-scare incident at Mangaluru International Airport (MIA) and successfully addressed public concerns and fears that it generated.”

Unfurling the national tricolour at the district Republic Day celebrations on Sunday, Poojari, also minister for ports, fisheries and religious endowment, backed the steps taken by the city police in defusing the crisis that the IED scare generated.

“I recall with pride the role that Gangaiah (of BDDS) and other policemen played,” he said, adding the state and central governments are committed to ensuring that people of the district lead a peaceful life.

The minister’s backing of police action assumes significance in that former chief minister H D Kumaraswamy had described the entire incident as an elaborate ‘drill’ to defuse nothing more than a bag that contained ‘mini mini’ powder aka gunpowder. The city police brass, without getting into the political maelstrom their action generated, maintained that the abandoned backpack found at Mangaluru International Airport (MIA) on January 20 indeed had an IED in it.

On farmer’s welfare, Poojari said 1.3 lakh farmers in Dakshina Kannada have benefitted from the Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi, wherein they receive Rs 6,000 from the Centre and an additional Rs 4,000 from the state government.

The two governments have already released three instalments under this fund, aimed at recognising the contribution of farmers to food security of the nation, and the fourth instalment will be released shortly,” he said.

Likewise, 67,620 farmers have benefited to a tune of Rs 526.5 crore by way of the move by the government to waive up to Rs 1 lakh of short-term agriculture loan availed by them from cooperative institutions in the district. In all, 417 economically backward women from minority communities have received aid of Rs 2.1 crore for their marriage. The religious endowment department has started Sapthapadhi, a similar scheme in 100 endowment temples, he said.

The government has taken steps to construct a 300-bed medicine superspeciality block at Wenlock Hospital at a cost of Rs 28 crore. This block will house a 31-bed medical intensive care unit, the minister said, adding the country’s first integrated AYUSH Hospital that is being constructed at a cost of Rs 8 crore too will come on the district hospital campus.

These new facilities will give a fillip to healthcare in the government side, the minister noted.

Earlier, Poojari received a guard of honour from 18 marching contingents at an impressive parade.

NCC Air Wing senior cadets and their Army counterparts were adjudged the top two marching contingents. Students from various schools presented a vibrant cultural programme on the occasion. The administration honoured bureaucrats with Sarvothham awards and district Kannada Rajyotsava awards, for achievers in diverse fields, on the occasion.

Title: NMC HO gardens, trees to grow on treated sewage
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) in association with a Japan-based company has installed a mini sewage treatment plant (STP) on a nullah situated in front of the head office. The treated sewage from mini STP will be utilized to grow trees and gardens situated on the premises of the NMC head office in Civil Lines.

Mayor Sandip Joshi inaugurated the mini STP on January 26. Deputy mayor Manisha Kothe, municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar, ruling party leader Sandip Jadhav, leader of opposition group Tanaji Wanve, chairman of NMC water works’ consultative committee Vijay Zalke, superintending engineer Shweta Banerjee, executive engineer Manoj Ganvir, Abhijit Gan of Rite Water Solution and others were present.

The nullah, situated in front of the NMC’s new administrative building, emanates foul smell due to the flow of sewage water. Now, the mini STP, installed with a capacity of 5,000 litres, will treat sewage and water trees and gardens of NMC’s head office.

In 2016, the NMC had installed a similar mini STP at a garden situated in Narendra Nagar. At that time, the NMC had announced installation of similar mini STPs on all nullahs and usage of treated sewage to water gardens and construction sites.

The mini STP can be installed with capacity of 1,000 litres to 50,000 litres.

Title: Kannada Rajyotsava awards presented to 32 achievers at Republic Day function
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

MANGALURU: District Kannada Rajyotsava awards were given to 32 achievers, including Stanly Pinto , chief of bureau, ‘The Times of India’, Mangaluru edition, nearly three months late. Kota Srinivas Poojari , district minister, conferred the awards at the district Republic Day celebration on Sunday, as they could not be presented at the Rajyotsava Day celebration due to the model code of conduct being in force due to the Mangaluru City Corporation elections.

Awardees

The awardees are H K Nayanadu (arts and literature), Prashanth Jogi, Ashok Polali, A Raghunath Sherigar, Jagadish Acharya, Rajesh Vittla, Lakshmi Narayana aka Annu Poojary, M Adhvik Shetty and Tharanath Pambada (arts); Y Jagadish Rao, S K Anand Kumar, Sridhar Gowda, Vasanth Salian, Suresh Rai Nodimullu, Venkappa Kajava and N S Umesh Devadiga, Umar Beejadakatte, Narayan Naik and Bharath Kumar (social service); Harishchandra P Salian (literature); Ruthwik Alevooraya K V, Pradeep Kumar, Rakshith Shetty, Anagha (sports); Gangadhar Puthran aka Ganesh Bolar (environmentalist); Sarayu Bala Yakshavrunda Makkala Mela (arts institution); Sri Vinayak Friends Club, Athma Shakti Multi-Purpose Cooperative Society, Seva Bharati and Biruver Kudla (social service institutions); and Pundalik Pai aka Annu Mangaluru (journalism).

Sarvottham Awards conferred

The administration also conferred the Sarvottham awards given to government officials across ranks in recognition of their meritorious and dedicated service to public life on the occasion. The awardees are Dr Ramakrishna Rao, district health and family welfare officer, Wilma Elizabeth Tauro, labour officer; Vatsala, deputy tahsildar; B Ugappa Moolya, panchayat development officer; Anand S Banjan, assistant engineer, minor irrigation department; Sumangala, nurse; Prakash Nayak, shirasthedar; Rathnakar Kottari, second division assistant; Kumaraswamy, village accountant and M Devadas, senior vehicle driver.

Title: CAA march: University of Hyderabad students detained
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Police detain UoH students protesting on campus against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act on account of Republic... Read More

HYDERABAD: Mild tension prevailed at the University of Hyderabad, on Sunday, after policemen deployed at the main entrance stopped students heading towards the Ambedkar statue, Masjid Banda, to participate in the ‘Save the Constitution’ march. Cops even detained some of them, including student union president Abhishek Nandan , forcing students to stage a dharna near the main entrance of the varsity.

The anti-CAA (Citizen Amendment Act) and anti-NRC (National Register of Citizens) march was organised by the UoH students union.

“We just wanted to garland the Ambedkar Statue at Masjid Banda, but the police forcibly stopped us at the main gate. Heavy police force was deployed at the gate and they barricaded the main entrance. They even brought water cannons to stop students from reaching the Ambedkar statue,” said Nandan. Following the police action, students continued their protest at the main gate where they raised slogans like ‘Telangana police go back’, ‘Inquilab Zindabad’, ‘Manuvad ho barbad’ and ‘Long live students unity'.

Similar protests took centre stage at Republic Day celebrations of other universities and institutes as well, including Maulana Azad National Urdu University (MANUU) and Tata Institute of Social Sciences (TISS). While TISS students organised a public talk in which Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad participated, MANUU students took out a Tiranga rally on campus against CAA , NRC , and NPR — from the Union Office to the Open Air Theatre inside the campus. Manuu students also launched a postcard campaign.

“We will send one lakh postcards to the President of India demanding that he repel CAA and not implement NRC and NPR. We will start sending them from Monday and continue till February 1. We also request students of other varsities to participate in the programme,” said Umar Faruq Quadri, president, student union, Manuu. Students also demanded the that centre release Rs 500 crore for the varsity to enable them to complete construction work, clear pending salary dues, and release scholarship dues for students. Mohammed Abdul Aziz of Movement for Peace and Justice, Layeeq Ahmed Khan, national secretary of the Fraternity Movement and Khaleeda Praveen, an activist along with 300 students participated in the Tiranga rally.

Title: K Chandrasekhar Rao cannot be trusted, says MP N Uttam Kumar Reddy
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

MP N Uttam Kumar Reddy

HYDERABAD: Telangana Congress president and Nalgonda MP N Uttam Kumar Reddy has termed chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao's stand against CAA as “political drama.”

He read out the preamble of the Indian Constitution after unfurling the national flag at Gandhi Bhavan and said that CAA and NRC are against provisions of the Constitution. AICC had directed its state leaders to read out the preamble to create awareness among the people about CAA.

Responding to KCR's announcement that Telangana Assembly would pass an anti-CAA resolution, he said despite repeated demands by him for a special Assembly session on the issue, KCR remained silent all these days. “Immediately after poll results, KCR has begun a new drama. HE cannot be trusted as he keeps changing his stance,” he said.

Title: Drizzle helps raise temp a bit, rain expected today
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

New Delhi: The maximum and minimum temperatures rose by a few notches on Monday following drizzle in parts of the city owing to a western disturbance .

India meteorological department (IMD) has forecast a spell of light rain on Tuesday as well, with isolated parts of the capital receiving hail.

Delhi’s minimum temperature has gradually been rising over the last 48 hours. On Sunday, it was recorded at 6.9 degrees Celsius, and it rose to 8.5 degrees Celsius on Monday. It is likely to touch 11 degrees by Tuesday. “Both the maximum and the minimum have risen due to a western disturbance. Its withdrawal after 48 hours and the resulting rain will lead to a drop in temperatures once again. Parts of Delhi recorded very light rain on Monday, but the intensity will be higher on Tuesday,” said Kuldeep Srivastava, scientist at IMD.

Delhi’s maximum temperature on Monday was recorded at 23 degrees Celsius– one degree above normal. Srivastava says the maximum is likely to fall to around 19 degrees on Tuesday due to overcast conditions.

Between 8.30 am and 5.30 pm, the Lodhi road and Ridge stations received ‘trace’ rainfall, while parts of west Delhi also received a drizzle. The relative humidity in the last 24 hours oscillated between 58 and 100 per cent.

Forecast for Tuesday shows light rain in the morning, accompanied by hailstorm in isolated pockets. Strong surface winds in the range of 20-25 km/hr are also likely to occur. Delhi’s air quality, meanwhile, was recorded in ‘very poor’ range with an air quality index of 345.

Title: Nobody can break Bharat, says Asaduddin Owaisi on Sharjeel Imam’s comment
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: Condemning JNU student leader, Sharjeel Imam ’s controversial comment about Assam, AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi said that India is not chicken’s neck that it can be broken.

Speaking late on Saturday night, the Hyderabad MP expressed dissatisfaction over the comment and said, “No one can either break Bharat, or a region from it. This is a country, not a murgi’s neck. You should not resort to such talk.” Owaisi added, “Whoever is doing so, I don’t accept it and I condemn such wahiyad (nonsense) talk.”

In a video that went viral, Imam was heard saying, “If we want to help Assam, we should block the way for armed forces,” branding Assam as chicken’s neck. Assam Police as well as Aligarh Police have registered a case against Imam.

Meanwhile, Owaisi, on Republic Day, hoisted the National Flag at Madina Building Cross Road, (south zone) and read the Preamble. Owaisi wanted to hoist the national flag on the intervening night of January 25 and 26 at Charminar but police denied permission.

“If police allows, I will form a human chain on January 30,”said Owaisi. The chain will be formed as mark of protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register ( NPR ).

Title: Mangaluru firing victims kin celebrate Republic Day
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

MANGALURU: Republic Day was celebrated by hoisting the tricolour at Azizuddin Road , Bunder , on Sunday.

Children of Jaleel Bengre hoisted the flag and several activists participated. Jaleel Bengre, 49, and Nauseen Kudroli , 23, were killed in alleged police firing on December 19, after the anti-CAA protests turned violent. Activists have decided to fight till the families are compensated. It may be recalled that the government had withdrawn ex gratia after announcing the same. Activists have demanded a judicial probe into the incident.

Title: Hindus in Lanka not facing persecution like in Pak, Af, Desh: RSS
Content:
This story is from January 27, 2020

Nagpur: Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh’s (RSS) Sarkaryavah (general secretary) Suresh (Bhaiyaji) Joshi said the Hindus of Sri Lanka are not facing any persecution problems like those in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh. Joshi is no. 2 in RSS hierarchy after Sarsanghchalak Mohan Bhagwat.

Talking to newspersons on the sidelines of a flag-hoisting function held at the RSS headquarters in Mahal locality of Nagpur, Joshi said the issue of allowing Tamil Hindus of Sri Lanka into the ambit of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) was taken up in Tamil Nadu. "However, it is seen that Hindus living in that country are not facing the kind of troubles like those in the three countries covered under CAA," he said.

Amid protests against CAA and NRC, political parties including Congress, have raised the question of not including the Sri Lankan Tamils into the law. As he took questions on the anti CAA-NRC protests, Joshi said there has been no discrimination against followers of Islam in India.
